member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseTextLengthCondition
member.summary: BaseTextLengthCondition compares a number of elements in a text field to a minimum and maximum. The user can test against one or both.

remarks.para:
This is an abstract base class. Subclass to determine if the number of elements is determined in characters, words or something else. You will supply the client and server side evaluation functions in
and respectively. This class provides a framework with the main evaluation functions.
See the Developer's Guide for details.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseTextLengthCondition.EvaluateCondition
member.summary: Evaluates as "success" when returns a value that is between the minimum and maximum. Evaluates as "failed" otherwise. There is no "cannot evaluate" result.

remarks.para: If both and are assigned, it adds the total element count of each before comparing to the minimum and maximum.
Minimum and Maximum must be non-zero to be evaluated.

member.returns: 1 for success; 0 for failed

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.TextLengthCondition
member.summary: TextLengthCondition compares the length of a text field to a minimum and maximum number of characters.

remarks.para: See the User's Guide for an overview of using this condition.
Establish the minimum with and maximum with .
This condition supports up to two textboxes in and . When both are used, the total characters of the two are compared to the Minimum and Maximum.
While <input type='text' /> fields support a maxlength, <textarea> elements do not. This condition is very useful to limit the entry in multiline TextBoxes.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.WordCountCondition
member.summary: WordCountCondition compares the number of words in a text field to a minimum and maximum. The user can test against one or both.

remarks.para: A "word" is a sequential string of characters that are all letters, numbers, the underscore and single quote. Single quote allows possessive and contraction terms to be one word. All other characters are word separators. Thus characters like punctuation and double quotes are no different than spaces.
See the User's Guide for an overview of using this condition.
Establish the minimum with and maximum with .
This condition supports up to two textboxes in and . When both are used, the total words of the two are compared to the Minimum and Maximum.

remarks.para: The user identifies an into the list which will be evaluated, starting at 0. They identify a state in the property, true or false, indicating if its selected/checked. When the values match, the condition evaluates as "success".

member.summary: Gets and sets the position within the list to have its state evaluated. The state at that position is compared to .

value.para: Starts at 0. If you supply an index beyond the end of the list, it will not evaluate.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.SelectedIndexCondition.Selected
member.summary: Gets and sets the state of the list's selection at the position in Index.

value.para: If the state at the position of matches this value, the condition evaluates as "success".
When evaluating to a CheckBoxList or RadioButtonList, it compares to the Checked property on the control. Otherwise, it compares the SelectedIndex property to Index.
It defaults to true.

member.summary: The client-side evaluation function depends on the class of control. For CheckBoxList and RadioButton list, this returns "VAM_EvalSelIdxCheckCond". For list boxes and drop down lists, this returns "VAM_EvalSelIdxListCond".

member.summary: CountSelectionsCondition evaluates CheckBoxLists and ListBoxes to determine if the number of selections is between a minimum and maximum.

remarks.para: Since it is based on , the user can select up to two fields whose combined total will be evaluated. The two controls must be of the same control class because the client side code sets up one evaluation function and it differs depending on the control.
Set the property to the control whose selection to count. If desired, set a second control with the property. Set the and properties to establish the valid range of selections.
See the User's Guide for an overview of using this condition.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CustomCondition
member.summary: The page developer defines the client side evaluation function, identified in , and the server side evaluation method using the event.

remarks.para: CustomCondition is one way to allow users to provide custom Conditions without subclassing. All Conditions have the ServerCondition event handler and CustomEvalFunctionName property. This allows you to use any existing condition class and override both client and server side evaluation functions. You would do this if the properties offered on the condition are useful to your condition evaluation function.
This class provides and as properties which can optionally be used within the client- and server-side evaluation functins.
The base class, , normally requires both ControlID properties to be assigned. This class overrides that behavior.
The ControlIDToEvaluate and SecondConrolIDToEvaluate properties allow ALL control classes to be assigned because the user's logic will figure out how to evaluate these controls.
See the User's Guide for an overview of using this condition.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.FixedResultCondition
member.summary: FixedResultCondition always evaluates to a fixed value of "success" or "failed" based on the setting in .

remarks.para: FixedResultCondition is used by the . It is never available in the vam.config file (for selection within the Properties Editor).
Its method always returns 1 when Result is true and 0 when Result is false.

The idea is that IgnoreConditionValidator does not evaluate on the client-side or in VAMPage.ValidateGroup. Instead, the ValidatorAction class initializes the BaseValidatorAction.IsValid property to true and expects the page developer to set that property to false within their post back code as needed. The client-side maintains that setting with the client side evaluation function VAM_EvalFixed().
For example, they compare a string in a textbox to a database lookup. If that comparision does not match, the validator is IsValid=false which shows the error message.

In traditional conditions, you would split your logic between two places, the condition and the code that would take the data look up an use it for something. Why not simply let the user perform the look-up on the post back event handler and if there is a problem, simply set IsValid=false and regenerate the page?

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletSession
member.summary: A portal-safe version of the session collection
member.remarks:
The session is a name/value pair store that is specific to a user. The data is perserved only for the current session. As soon as the user logs off or their session expires all the data is lost.
Any serializable object may be stored in the session

member.summary: Constructs a portlet session object
member.param: The occurrence to construct the session for
The HTTP session, typically obtained through the System.Web.HttpContext.Current.Session property

member.summary: Removes a session variable from the store
member.param: The name of the session variable to remove

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletSession.Remove(System.String,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletSessionScope)
member.summary: Removes a sessoin variable from the store
member.param: The name of the session variable to remove
The scope at which the session variable was stored

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletSession.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets or sets an object to or from the session
member.remarks: The scope of this data is automatically set to PortletSessionScope.PortletShortcut

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletSession.Item(System.String,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletSessionScope)
member.summary: Gets or sets an object to or from the session
member.remarks:
Storing data with different scopes allows different instances or occurrences of the same portlet to share data.
Data stored at the PortletSessionScope.PortletShortcut level can only be read by the same occurrence that stored the data, where as data stored at the PortletSessionScope.Portlet level could be retrieved or modified by any occurrence of that portlet . Similarly, data stored at the PortletSessionScope.Global level is accessible by all instances and occurrences of that portlet
All names are unique to their scope and do not interfere with each other in any way. For instance, data stored with the name "MyData" at the scope of PortletSessionScope.PortletShortcut has no affect on data stored with the same name but with a scope of PortletSessionScope.Portlet. They are treated as completely distinct pieces of data.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MSStyle.BaseValidator
member.remarks: BaseValidator mimics System.Web.UI.WebControls.BaseValidator. It is subclassed from VAM.BaseAnyValidator which means it inherits the many new properties automatically. So the user can start using the new features right away. There are only a few properties that use the same name but have a different implementation: * Display - Different enumerated types but they have matching names. Issue: programmatic assignment of the property will require changing System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidatorDisplay to Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidatorDisplay * ErrorMessage - When the BaseValidator.Text property is assigned, it becomes the error message and this becomes the SummaryErrorMessage. This rule will be enforced here, potentially overwriting anything already in SummaryErrorMessage when Text is assigned. * ForeColor - VAM uses the style sheet to "VAMErrorText" to define color red as a default. MS.BaseValidator assigns ForeColor to red as a default. We'll assign ForeColor to red as well. This will allow the user to use the control without the style sheet file.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator
member.summary: A base class for building Validator controls.

remarks.para: BaseAnyValidator is subclassed from to expose the properties found on the base classes of , , , and .
It must be subclassed to define which instances of these classes belong.
It does not specify a ControlIDToEvaluate property. If you want that property, subclass from .
See the Developer's Guide for an overview of subclassing this class.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidator
member.summary: BaseValidator is a control that shows an error message HTML in its desired position on the page when its Condition indicates "failure".

remarks.para: Most of the work is done by the subclass assigned to the property. That class contains the property that supplies the subclass used to determine if the error message is shown or hidden.

Aside from providing a location for the error message on the page, the BaseValidator control exposes properties on the ValidatorAction and Condition so the user can easily edit them in the Properties Editor and have them written into the control's attributes instead of innertext in the ASP.NET text representation of the control. Properties are transferred to the ValidatorAction and Condition during OnPreRender through the method.
Each BaseValidator subclass generally has its own ValidatorAction subclass. If you create a new Condition or ValidatorAction and want to avoid building a BaseValidator subclass, use the .
See the Developer's Guide documentation for extensive details on creating your own Validator controls.

This class is very lightweight. Generally you will use or subclass the class because it exposes the properties found on BaseCondition and BaseValidationAction. BaseValidator should only be subclassed when you want to re-invent the Validator control. It only features validation capabilities. It doesn't even have an ErrorFormatter.

member.summary: IsValid indicates that the validator is valid or not. In other words, the condition evaluates as success or failed.

value.para: It is set by a call to . Prior to that, its value is true. You can change the value of this property manually after validation has taken place. This allows you to override the validation result, if necessary. The uses this technique.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.ServerCondition
member.summary: ServerCondition is an event handler that allows users to replace the built-in EvaluateCondition method on the Condition with custom code.

remarks.para: Users can instantiate any of the non-base Condition classes and use it. The idea is to select one whose properties are useful to your condition. Often, the user writes very specific code that knows every condition in the code and doesn't need any user configuration settings on the property. They'd use CustomCondition, a child class of BaseCondition, because it lacks other properties.
While this event handler passes pArg as ConditionEventArgs, subclasses of BaseCondition may provide a subclass of ConditionEventArgs.

item.description: uses which provides references to the control and its textual value.
uses which provides references to both controls and their textual values.

remarks.para: When writing a ServerCondition function, access all public properties directly from the pSourceCondition parameter (after typecasting).
The task of this event handler is to set either the IsMatch or CannotEvaluate properties based on what is detected from fields on the page.
Transferred to Condition.ServerCondition in .

It defaults to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.Enabler
member.summary: Enabler is a condition which runs prior to the rest of the conditions. Use it to turn on and off the validator based on conditions on the page.

value.para: For example, this validator should not run unless a certain checkbox is checked. VAM supplies a number of conditions including the Specialized Conditions that test non-data attributes like Visibility () and Enabled () to support this property.
When no enabler is needed, it is null.
It defaults to null.
Transferred to ValidatorAction.Enabler in .
It provides the UITypeEditor to select the condition in the Properties Editor.

The Properties Editor and ASP.NET Attributes do not support a way to write out a polymorphic property. So this property is not written into the ASP.NET text. Instead, the object is kept in the collection and limits that collection to one item. ASP.NET attributes can write out a collection and provides with a workaround to the polymorphism problem.
It uses this ASP.NET format:

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.EnablerContainer
member.summary: EnablerContainer is a hack to allow the property to stream between ASP.NET and an object.

value.para: The Enabler property itself doesn't stream but modifies this list as a hack to work around a limitation in the ASP.NET attributes that don't know how to handle a polymorphic property.
This class streams to the ASP.NET text but does not appear in the Properties Editor.
You shouldn't attempt to add more than one condition as only the first will be applied to Enabler.
It uses this ASP.NET format:

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.SupportClientSideLookupByID
member.summary: SupportClientSideLookupByID allows JavaScript programmers to get to the Action object on the client side by calling the VAM_FindAOById function with the ClientID of the owner control.

value.para: Use the client-side function VAM_FindAOById to search for the action that matches the clientID you specify. That function will return null if not found. Use the Action object to modify it, such as changing the Enabled property.
When this property is true, two things happen:
1. The ID is written as a property, CID, into the control.

2. If the Enabled property is false, normally no code is written to the client side. This is overridden and code is generated so users can toggle the enabled property. Note that client-side code is NEVER generated when the browser doesn't support it or the EnableClientScript property is false.

example.para: This shows how to use the VAM_FindAOById() function to retrieve an action object and change its Enabled property. This is JavaScript code.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.NotCondition
member.summary: NotCondition reverses the result of the ValidatorAction.Condition. method and its client side equivalent.

value.para: EvaluateCondition should not do anything with this property. ValidatorAction.Condition. applies it. Similarly, your client-side evaluation condition should not do anything with this property.
It defaults to false.
Transferred to Condition.NotCondition in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.Trim
member.summary: Determines that the evaluation should occur after trimming lead and trailing spaces from text values of fields.

value.para: When true, it should trim.
Set to false when your server side retrieval code for the field doesn't trim, thus would be tripped up by the lead and trailing spaces.
It defaults to true.
Transferred to Condition.Trim in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.CustomEvalFunctionName
member.summary: CustomEvalFunctionName allows a user to provide their own client-side evaluation function. When blank, the subclass supplies its function in EvalFunctionName.

value.para: This is usually used when setting up a custom condition with ServerCondition on the server side.
Condition (object) - client-side representation of the Condition object. Its properties can be useful in your custom function.
It returns one of three values:
0 = failed
1 = succeeded
-1 = cannot evaluate. (For example, the field is invisible.)
See the User's Guide for details and example.
Transferred to Condition.CustomEvalFunctionName in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.OverrideClientSideEvaluation
member.summary: When set to a value other than 'No', the client-side evaluation function supplied by this class is replaced with one that has special properties to show and hide the error message regardless of the data on the page.

remarks.para: Useful when writing custom server side functions that don't have an equivalent client-side function. This gives a slight client-side behavior, including blinking the error message on postback and hiding it after edits.

When 'No', the ValidatorAction.Condition. property provides the client-side evaluation function. Otherwise, this property causes the ValidatorAction.Condition. to be set to "VAM_EvalAltCS" and the OCSMode property to be added to the client-side object for use by VAM_EvalAltCS.
Transferred to Condition.OverrideClientSideEvaluation in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.ErrorMessage
member.summary: Gets and sets the message shown by the ErrorFormatter when it determines an invalid case.

value.para: It is a string, which optionally can contain HTML. However, HTML is recommended to be used carefully. VAM attempts to allow you to separate the HTML from the error message using the ErrorFormatter and style properties for tokens on the VAMPage class. This way, your error messages do not break the formatting when someone wants to change the wording.
The string can contain tokens, all uppercase one-word text enclosed in brackets.
It defaults to "".
It provides the UITypeEditor to edit the property in a large textbox and select tokens.
Transferred to BaseValidatorAction.ErrorMessage in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.ErrorMessageLookupID
member.summary: ErrorMessageLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the error message is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the ErrorMessage.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of error messages so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time. It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the ErrorMessage that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.

When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned. If no match is found OR this is blank, ErrorMessage will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMessageGroupName.
It defaults to "".
Transferred to BaseValidatorAction.ErrorMessageLookupID in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.SummaryErrorMessage
member.summary: SummaryErrorMessage is the message shown in the control when this validator has a condition that reports "failure". If blank, the ValidationSummary control uses the instead.

value.para: It is a string, which optionally can contain HTML. However, HTML is recommended to be used carefully. VAM attempts to allow you to separate the HTML from the error message using style sheets and style properties for tokens on the VAMPage class. This way, your error messages do not break the formatting when someone wants to change the wording.
The string can contain tokens, all uppercase one-word text enclosed in brackets.
It defaults to "".
Transferred to BaseValidatorAction.ErrorMessageLookupID in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.SummaryErrorMessageLookupID
member.summary: SummaryErrorMessageLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the summary error message is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the SummaryErrorMessage.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of summary error messages so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time.
It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the SummaryErrorMessage that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.
When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned.
If no match is found OR this is blank, SummaryErrorMessage will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMessageGroupName.
It defaults to "".
Transferred to BaseValidatorAction.SummaryErrorMessageLookupID in .

value.para: The group name "" is a valid name and all validators, validator summary and submit buttons default to "".
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.EventsThatValidate
member.summary: EventsThatValidate determines which client side events are fired to validate.

value.para: There are two events: onchange and onsubmit. By default, both fire to validate. When you setup the validator to display an alert or other feedback on change, the message may not be needed. Use this to determine which of these events activate the message.
When set to OnChange, no server side validation is performed. Use this state to show a warning message about the data without preventing the user from submitting the page.
It defaults to All.
Transferred to BaseValidatorAction.EventsThatValidate in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAnyValidator.ShowRequiredFieldMarker
member.summary: ShowRequiredFieldMarker adds a control to the left of the error message.

value.para: Use it as a shortcut to setting up the RequiredFieldMarker. The marker is always visible.
Always place it on the leftmost validator. Otherwise, it may be pushed to the right as a validator is shown between the field and the RequiredFieldMarker.
It uses the system wide defaults found in . If you need to customize the settings, manually add a RequiredFieldMarker.
Transferred to BaseValidatorAction.ShowRequiredFieldMarker in .

member.remarks: BaseCompareValidator is an abstract base class for validators that handle comparisions: CompareValidator and RangeValidator. These validators evaluate strings where the user selects a Type. To maintain compatibility with MS Validators, the Type will continue to use the ValidationDataType enumeration instead of VAM's VAMTypeConverters. We will map ValidationDataTypes to VAMTypeConverters with MapType(). Supported: CanConvert static method Not supported: CutoffYear property and GetFullYear method because they are protected.

member.summary: ClientValidationFunction is the name of the javascript client side function that implements the validation function using Microsoft's function definition. It is called by a javascript wrapper function, VAM_MSCompatCustomCond or VAM_MSCompatOneFldCustomCond, which translates VAM's EvalFunctionMethod to Microsoft's parameters. Defaults to "".

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MSStyle.MSCompatCustomCondition
member.remark: MSCompatCustomCondition is used when CustomValidator.ControlToValidate is blank. It maps the server side and client side evaluation functions from their Microsoft style to VAM. Server side - System.Web.UI.WebControls.ServerValidateEventArgs contains two properties. * Value - will be blank because ControlToValidate is blank * IsValid - event must set it to true or false depending on the evaluation

member.summary: ClientValidationFunction is the name of the javascript client side function that implements the validation function using Microsoft's function definition. It is called by a javascript wrapper function, VAM_MSCompatCustomCond or VAM_MSCompatOneFldCustomCond, which translates VAM's EvalFunctionMethod to Microsoft's parameters. Defaults to "".

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MSStyle.MSCompatOneFieldCustomCondition
member.remark: MSCompatOneFieldCustomCondition is used when CustomValidator.ControlToValidate is assigned. It maps the server side and client side evaluation functions from their Microsoft style to VAM. Server side - System.Web.UI.WebControls.ServerValidateEventArgs contains two properties. * Value - will be the text value from ControlToValidate * IsValid - event must set it to true or false depending on the evaluation By having a ControlToValidate, the client-side will hookup a event to fire when ControlToValidate is changed.

Uses System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummaryDisplayMode. Maps to the same named property on VAM.ValidationSummary - HeaderText - ShowSummary. member.summary: Group is the group name to which this ValidationSummary is associated. Submit buttons are assigned group names, including "", "*" and a name. The button group must match this value or match "*" to show this validation summary. One ValidationSummary can support multiple groups by providing a pipe delimited list of group names. For example: "Group1|Group2". Lead and trailing spaces around each group name will be ignored and can be used for formatting. Defaults to "".

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SImage
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the Image control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

remarks.para: AutoSortArrayList extends the ArrayList to manage a list that is always sorted. For details, see the header of this file.
You can retrieve this with documentation and sort at http://www.peterblum.com/CollectionsLibrary/AutoSortArrayList.aspx.

member.summary: Storage for xIComparer.

member.summary: Constructor which sets xAutoSortB.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.Add(System.Object)
member.summary: Inserts an item into the collection.

remarks.para: It adds to the end if xAutoSortB is false.
Otherwise, it adds in the sorted order as determined by BinarySearch(xIComparer).

member.exception: If called when xDuplicatesAllowedB is false and you add a duplicate instance.
member.returns: The position inserted into the list, starting at 0.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.AddRange(System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: AddRange is overridden to enforce sorting when xAutoSortB is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.Contains(System.Object)
member.summary: Contains is overridden to use BinarySearch when xAutoSort is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.BinarySearch(System.Object)
member.summary: BinarySearch is overridden to enforce the xIComparer property.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.IndexOf(System.Object)
member.summary: IndexOf is overridden to optimize the search using BinarySearch when xAutoSortB is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.IndexOf(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: IndexOf is overridden to optimize the search using BinarySearch when xAutoSortB is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.IndexOf(System.Object,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: IndexOf is overridden to optimize the search using BinarySearch when xAutoSortB is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.Insert(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Insert is overridden to prevent inserting when xAutoSortB is true. You should use Add() instead. Will throw the exception InvalidOperationException if called when xAutoSortB is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.InsertRange(System.Int32,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: InsertRange is overridden to prevent inserting when xAutoSortB is true. You should use AddRange instead. Will throw the exception InvalidOperationException if called when xAutoSortB is true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.Sort
member.summary: Sort is overridden to enforce the xIComparer property

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.Reverse
member.summary: Reverse is overridden to prevent reversing when xAutoSortB is true. You should supply an IComparer that reverses the sort and call Sort().
member.exception: If called when xAutoSortB is true

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.Reverse(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reverse is overridden to prevent reversing when xAutoSortB is true. You should supply an IComparer that reverses the sort and call Sort().
member.exception: If called when xAutoSortB is true

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.SetRange(System.Int32,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: SetRange is overridden to prevent its use when xAutoSortB is true. You must delete the original items in the range and call AddRange. This could have been done automatically here but that changes the definition of SetRange where order is implied.
member.exception: If called when xAutoSortB is true

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.xAutoSortB
member.summary: xAutoSortB indicates if auto sorting is on.

remarks.para: When true, Add() and AddRange() will insert the object in the position provided by BinarySearch. A number of methods will raise InvalidOperationException when true: Insert(), InsertRange(), and Reverse(). When false, all methods follow use their ancestor's functionality.

If set to false and you add items, when you set it back to true, Add() and AddRange() can incorrectly position data as a binary search is used to position data. So if switching from false to true, call Sort().

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.xIComparer
member.summary: xIComparer provides an IComparer interface for use with Sort() and BinarySearch().

remarks.para: By default, these methods use the IComparer methods of the objects you insert into the list. For primitive values, this works well. For strings, you may consider .
But for custom objects, you'll need to help with an IComparer.
It defaults to null.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CollectionsLibrary.AutoSortArrayList.xDuplicatesAllowedB
member.summary: xDuplicatesAllowedB determines if a duplicate is allowed into the list.

remarks.para: This only applies with xAutoSortB is true.
If Add() detects a duplicate when this is false, an InvalidOperationException is thrown.
It defaults to false.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortalPageBase
member.summary: The base class for portal pages
member.remarks:
All pages used to display portlets within the portal must inherit from PortalPageBase.
The portal page lifecycle is as follows:
1.) OnInit 2.) ProcessPortalURL 3.) InitializePortalPage 4.) BuildOutterGrid 5.) BuildPortletGrid 6.) SyncronizePortletStates 7.) LoadPostData 8.) OnLoad 9.) Control Events (Button clicks, etc.) 10.) OnPreRender 11.) RenderPageSSLScript 12.) AppendPageCredentialControls 13.) AppendBrowserRefreshDetectionControls 14.) SaveViewState 15.) Render 16.) Dispose 17.) OnUnload

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortalPageBase.BrowserRefreshID
member.summary: Gets the current browser refresh ID
member.remarks:
The refresh ID is used to determine whether or not the current postback was caused by a user hitting their browser refresh button
To determine this check the IsBrowserRefresh property
The ID is unique for each instance of the page that is created and is written down to the resulting html page
The ID is also stored in session and is removed when a postback occurs.
The property returns an empty guid (Guid.Empty) if the page has not experienced a postback

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortalPageBase.IsBrowserRefresh
member.summary: Gets whether or not the current page instance was created in response to a user clicking the refresh button in their browser window after doing a postback
member.remarks:
This property makes it easier to prevent events from being fired in response to a browser refresh. If the property returns true then event handling code (such as that in an button click event hanlder) should probably be bypassed to prevent unexpected behavior.
This property will only return true if IsPostBack is true. (Page refreshes that occur when no previous postback has occured are not tracked.)

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletBase.PortletViewState
member.summary: Gets the viewstate for a portlet that is accessible to the screens and overlays for that portlet
member.remarks:
This is useful for storing values when going from one screen or view to another. While the viewtate for a screen is lost when a new screen is loaded, the parent portlet's viewstate is maintained as long as the portlet is loaded on the page.
Only when the portlet is unloaded from the page, a new page is visited, or a Response.Redirect occurs will the viewstate for the parent portlet be lost.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletBase.Session
member.summary: Gets a scoped, portal-safe version of the ASP.NET session object
member.remarks: Data that is portlet-specific should never be stored using the ASP.NET sessoin object The PortletSession object ensures data is stored on a per-portlet basis and that portlets cannot corrupt each other's session data

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletBase.PersistantState

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortletBase.IsBrowserRefresh
member.summary: Gets whether or not the current page instance was created in response to a user clicking the refresh button in their browser window after doing a postback
member.remarks:
This property makes it easier to prevent events from being fired in response to a browser refresh. If the property returns true then event handling code (such as that in an button click event hanlder) should probably be bypassed to prevent unexpected behavior.
This property will only return true if IsPostBack is true. (Page refreshes that occur when no previous postback has occured are not tracked.)

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor
member.summary: BaseDropDownListTypeEditor can be subclassed to build UITypeEditors that show a drop down list in the Visual Studio.Net property editor. You only need to override the method.

remarks.para: NOTE: Extracted from UITypeEditorClasses.cs in the PeterBlum.com UITypeEditors prodect.

It provides the internal global that is used by most of VAM's UITypeEditors to work properly in a nested Property Grid form. These UITypeEditors assign their Context.Container to OverrideContainer in their EditValue method and restore it to null when that method finishes.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.OverrideContainer
member.summary: Normally, EditValue is passed pContext with a value Container property. However, when nested within a Property Grid (including from a CollectionEditor), pContext.Container = null. Since Container is essential for building a list of controls found on the page, we use OverrideContainer to get the container. It is assigned by any class I develop using a Property Grid to contain the Container passed to that Property Grid UITypeEditor. If null, continue to use pContext.Container.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.fEdSvc
member.summary: fEdSrc is created and nulled in EditValue. It is here only to allow the value to be shared with the List_Click event handler

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.GetEditStyle(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext)
member.summary: GetEditStyle must be overridden for any UITypeEditor. In this case, we are using a DropDown style.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.EditValue(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext,System.IServiceProvider,System.Object)
member.summary: EditValue must be overridden from UITypeEditor to install a control that appears in the drop down.

remarks.para: For UITypeEditorEditStyle.DropDown, here is the general procedure:
1. Get the Edit Service from pProvider.GetService(typeof(IWindowsFormsEditorService)). It contains methods to run the DropDown and Forms interfaces.

2. Get a Window control instance that reflects the UI you want. In this case, its a ListBox. If you wanted multiple controls, consider something like the Panel class and add controls to its Controls list.
3. We want the ListBox to close on a Click event much like boolean and enum dropdowns do. So we set up a Click event handler that calls CloseDropDown on the Edit Service.
4. Add data to the ListBox.
5. Set the initial value of the list. pValue contains that value.
6. Let the Edit Service open and manage the DropDown interface.
7. Return the value from the list.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.GetSelectedItem(System.Object)
member.summary: GetSelectedItem is called before popping up the list to convert pValue into an item that will be selected in the list. This version simply returns pValue which means the list contains pValue itself.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.GetResult(System.Object)
member.summary: GetResult is called after the user closes the list only when there is a selection. It is passed the value of ListBox.SelectedItem. It should return an object that will be returned to the Property Editor. In this class, it returns pSelectedItem.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.List_Click(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: List_Click is a click event handler for the ListBox. We want the have the list close when the user clicks, just like the Enum and Bool types do in their UITypeEditors.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDropDownListTypeEditor.FillInList(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext,System.IServiceProvider,System.Windows.Forms.ListBox)
member.summary: FillInList must be overriden to supply properties to the ListBox.

remarks.para: It is essential to assign objects to the ListBox.Items collection. You can also customize other properties.
Your data does not need to be strings. Window forms list boxes offer customizable drawing rules which you can use to represent any kind of object.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SCheckBox
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the CheckBox control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction
member.summary: BaseValidatorAction is an action specifically for Validators. It requires an owner control based on and an Condition, either passed in or defined by the subclass.

remarks.para: It is part of four classes that when connected build a validator: , , , and BaseValidatorAction.
This class focuses on connecting the behaviors of a validator to an action.
The behaviors are:

item.description: create and format error messages shown at the location of the validator control including replacing tokens.
show and hide error information on the web page based on a condition
provide the error text to a ValidationSummary control

remarks.para: It contributes heavily to the client-side VAM system. By being a subclass of BaseAction, it already creates client-side VAM objects that represent itself. That means client-side onchange or onclick events are hooked up to call the client-side Action function "VAM_DoValidate". The Validator Action function builds the error message and shows or hides it based on the result of the condition. It offloads much of the work to client-side functions associated with the ErrorFormatter.
On the server side, it provides the method which is a wrapper around the DoAction method. It provides the and properties.
BaseValidatorAction has several key properties:

item.description: Condition - the BaseCondition subclass in use. Subclasses define which instance is used including letting the programmer decide.
ErrorFormatter - the BaseErrorFormatter subclass in use. Users always can select which is used through the ErrorFormatterType property.
Group - a name that associates validators together for a common submission.
ErrorMessage - the actual text used for the error message. It actually is customizable with tokens and other rules by subclasses.
SummaryErrorMessage - the text used by the ValidationSummary control. If not supplied, ErrorMessage is used. It too can support tokens and other rules by the subclasses.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction
member.summary: BaseAction defines the basics of an action. VAM defines these actions: , , , and .

remarks.para: There are essentially two elements to an action:
1. A condition which determines the actions behavior based on a Boolean value.
2. An action method which really can do whatever you define, based on the result of the condition's method.
Subclasses will typically act on elements of a page but one can imagine showing alerts, switching to another URL, or running some complex JavaScript to change the appearance of the page.
This class defines the property and a methodology to run an action after evaluating the condition.
The constructor always registers the instance with VAMPage.Actions.
See the Developer's Guide for details on this class.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.SetupComplete
member.summary: The Action is not considered ready for client-side code generation until the Owner.OnPreRender method sets this to true.

value.para: When the fPrepare flag indicates that the action is prepared, the method can be run on a control that is never used on the page. This is due to the control being contained in a parent ASP.NET control that is invisible or it gets added to the page in a DataGrid but never gets used because the user switches from the non-editable row to editable row mode after the control is created.
The Owner control must set this to true when its OnPreRender method runs successfully. Only when true will the VAMPage.PagePreRegister method use this Action object.
It defaults to false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.Condition
member.summary: Gets and sets the Condition used by this action.
member.value: If Owner is established on this Action object, it is immediately applied to the condition.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.Enabler
member.summary: Enabler is an optional condition that can turn on and off the evaluation of on both the server and client-side.

value.para: For example, this action should not run unless a certain checkbox is checked.
When no enabler is needed, it is null.
It defaults to null.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.ActionFunctionName
member.summary: ActionFunctionName is the name of the client side function that runs the action.

value.para: It is assigned to the MainFnc property on the client side VAM object.
Action object - while 'this' can be used to get the properties, this parm allows subclassing. So don't use 'this', use the action object to properties.

Condition Result (int) - the results of the Condition's evaluation. 1 = success, 0 = fail, -1 = cannot evaluate Some actions need to use the -1 state to restore appearances (like validators to hide the error msg)
Nothing.
See the Developer's Guide for details and an example.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.CanRunFunctionName
member.summary: CanRunFunctionName is the name of the client side function that determines if the action can be run. It checks the Enabler condition.

value.para: When its run, the Enabled property has already been verified. So this shouldn't handle Enabled.
It is assigned to the CanRun property on the client side representation of the Action object.
Action object
true - it can run; false - it cannot run.
It defaults to "VAM_CanRunActn". If "", there is no CanRun method.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.EnableClientScript
member.summary: EnableClientScript determines if client-side functionality is setup.
member.value:
When true, it sets up client-side scripting for this control. When false, no client-side code is written.
It defaults to true. This is part of several flags that can shut off client-side code. The class has several options to disable client-side scripting. The method is used to consolidate all the flags and determine if scripting is disabled.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.SupportClientSideLookupByID
member.summary: SupportClientSideLookupByID allows JavaScript programmers to get to the Action object on the client side by calling the VAM_FindAOById function with the ClientID of the owner control.

value.para: Use the client-side function VAM_FindAOById to search for the action that matches the clientID you specify. That function will return null if not found. Use the Action object to modify it, such as changing the Enabled property. When this is true, two things happen:
1. The ID is written as a property, CID, into the control.

2. If the Enabled property is false, normally no code is written to the client side. This is overridden and code is generated so users can toggle the enabled property. Note that client-side code is NEVER generated when the browser doesn't support it or the property is false.

example.para: This shows how to use the VAM_FindAOById() function to retrieve an action object and change its Enabled property. This is JavaScript code.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.AutoRunAction
member.summary: AutoRunAction determines if should run this class's server side method automatically as part of preparing the page.

value.para: It defaults to false.
An example of when true: FieldStateAction must setup the ControlToChange on the server side based on the condition so the client side has the correct initial appearance.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction.CSAutoRunAction
member.summary: CSAutoRunAction determines if the property is passed to the client side, instructing VAM_InitActions() to call VAM_DoAction() on this action immediately after all actions are initialized.
member.value: It defaults to false. Subclasses (FieldStateController) should set it to true if needed, often based on a user property.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.AddToPage(System.Boolean)
member.summary: AddToPage sets up the HTML and javascript from the and all other elements shown in the Validator control.

remarks.para: Assumes is in the desired state. Either has set it or its true to hide any validation information.
All HTML is added as child controls to the Owner (Validator) control.
This method does the following:

description.para: Adds the control when is true. The RequiredFieldMarker uses the default properties on for the image and text.

When the Validator control is absolutely positioned, the entire control is placed into an absolutely positioned <span> tag that uses the control's positioning so that the RequiredFieldMarker remains side-by-side with the ErrorFormatter.
If in design mode, it calls BaseErrorFormatter.AddDesignModeControls.
If at runtime, it calls BaseErrorFormatter.AddControls. If Globals.OnAdjustValidatorActionToBrowser is setup, that event is called first.
Preserves the VAMPage.ControlErrorCssClass in the attribute OrigCss for use on post back.

Calls to replace some or all tokens found in the message.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.SelectErrorMessage
member.summary: SelectErrorMessage returns the or another property containing a string for the error message as defined by a subclass.

remarks.para: When a subclass introduces more properties for various types of Error messages, it must override this method to select which error message is shown when the server side retrieves the error message.
For example, you may have strings for singular and plural forms of a sentence whose tokens contain numbers. ("There is one item selected." "There are 2 items selected.")
The client side has its own version of this method. See .

member.returns: The ErrorMessage property through . Override to return another property containing the appropriate error message to show for the situation.

For example, you may have strings for singular and plural forms of a sentence whose tokens contain numbers. ("There is one item selected." "There are 2 items selected.")
The client side has its own version of this method. See .

member.returns: The SummaryErrorMessage property through . Override to return another property containing the appropriate error message to show for the situation.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ReplaceMessageTokens(System.String,System.Boolean,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MessageType)
member.summary: ReplaceMessageTokens is passed an error message and replaces some or all of its tokens.

remarks.para: A token must be uppercase, alphanumeric, and enclosed in brackets. For example, "{COUNT}" or "{LABEL2}". A token can support singular and plural forms. It has the format {TOKENNAME:SINGULAR:PLURAL}. For example, "{COUNT:is:are}".
Subclasses define the tokens and thus this class does nothing but return the message passed as is.

Some tokens should always be processed on the server side. They include values that don't depend on conditions of fields. For example, properties on the validator - like a user supplied minimum value. Other tokens depend on the state of the control, such as showing the current length of a text field. They are called Runtime Tokens. These should be handled by the client-side Replace Token Function defined in . This method should update runtime tokens when the pApplyAllTokens parameter is true. In this case, the browser doesn't support client-side functions.
Call the method to handle most tokens. Call to handle singular/plural tokens.

member.param: The message containing tokens.
When true, assign all token types. When false, assign all except runtime tokens.
Determines whether message is going to the validator or the ValidationSummary control.
member.returns: The message with tokens replaced. This base class does not have any tokens defined and simply returns the original message.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ReplaceMessageToken(System.String,System.String,System.String,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.TokenType,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MessageType)
member.summary: ReplaceMessageToken replaces one token in pMsg with a new token. Call it from your overriden method.

remarks.para: It replaces all instances of the token passed in with the replacement passed in.

Optionally applies style sheet formatting around the token. The formatting uses the various style sheet properties on to build a <span> tag with a class= property around the token. The TokenType parameter determines the VAMPage property to use.
MessageType.ErrorFormatter only applies formatting when the ErrorFormatter.CanFormatTokens is true. MessageType.Summary always formats.
When you have a token that uses the singular:plural format, use .

member.param: The text containing tokens to change.
The token to replace. It must exactly match the text to replace including the brackets and uppercase text.
The text that replaces the token.
Identifies the type of token: property, runtime, label or other to select the formatting property from the VAMPage class.
Determines if the text will appear in the validator or ValidationSummary control. When this is "ErrorFormatter", formatting is only applied when the current ErrorFormatter.CanFormatTokens is true.
member.returns: The modified message with the one token specified replaced and optional formatting applied around that token.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ReplaceSingularPluralToken(System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: ReplaceSingularPluralToken replaces a special type of token that contains two strings. It evaluates a number. If the number = 1, it uses the first string. Otherwise it uses the second string. The result is this handles singular and plural forms and allows one message to switch to plural easily.

remarks.para: This method should be called from your override method.
The format of the token is : { + pTokenName + : + word + : + word + }
Examples: {COUNT:is:are} {EXCEEDS::s}
The TokenName is matched case sensitively.
The client-side code offers a similar function VAM_SPReplToken.

member.param: The text that contains the token.
The number to evaluate. If this is 1, the singular form is used. Otherwise the plural form is used.
The token name to find. It does not contain any brackets, colons or other parts of the complete token.
member.returns: The message with the token replaced in all locations that it is found.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.DefineProperties(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: Adds these properties to the client-side representation of the condition object: ErrMsg, SumMsg, SelErrMsg, SelSumMsg, Group, TokenRepl, EvtToVal, and IsValid. Plus calls BaseErrorFormatter.DefineProperties.

item.description: ErrorMessage with server side tokens assigned.
SummaryErrorMessage with server side tokens assigned.
SelErrMsgFunctionName
SelSumMsgFunctionName
Group forced to uppercase
TokenReplacementFunctionName. If "", not written.
EventsThatValidate converted to 0 = all, 1 = onsubmit, 2 = onchange
IsValid

member.param: The properties are appended to this stringbuilder.

member.returns: "VAL"

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.DescribeTokens(System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection)
member.summary: DescribeTokens allows the class to define a list of tokens and their descriptions for use within the Design Mode interface.

remarks.para: The UITypeEditor for ErrorMessage and SummaryErrorMessage properties will call this with a NameValueCollection. The class should define each token by calling pTokens.Add with the token as the key and a description as the value.
Descriptions should be kept short and not have any carriage returns because the interface shows it in one line.
remarks.code: pTokens.Add("{LABEL}", "The label field defined in the xLabelControlID property.");
remarks.para: When defining a token, the entire text you supply is inserted into the TextBox if it is selected from the context menu by the user. Singular/plural tokens should say "singular" and "plural" in the places for those words. For example, "{COUNT:singular:plural}".
Remember that tokens are case sensitive. So keep the token name all uppercase.

member.param: Add tokens into this collection where the name is the token itself and the value is a short description.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.TransferPropertiesFromControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.Int32)
member.summary: TransferPropertiesFromControl allows a third party control that is connected to ControlIDToEvaluate to provide some properties to this action, its condition, and its Condition.VAMTypeConverter.TransferPropertiesFromControl.

remarks.para: Some third party controls already have the same property values as the validator. So why have the user enter them twice? For example, if the control has an error message, it can copy it into ErrorMessage when ErrorMessage and ErrorMessageLookupID are both blank. For example, if this is a RangeCondition and the control has a minimum and maximum range setting, transfer those to RangeCondition.Minimum and Maximum. For example, set the DataType property or VAMTypeConverter.
This class only routes to the optional VAMTypeConverter. Subclass if you build a custom validator that uses a specialized control.

member.param: The control that associated with ControlIDToEvaluate that may supply its properties to this ValidatorAction and its Condition.
When the validator has more than one ControlIDToEvaluate, this specifies which one it is where 1 is the first, 2 is the second, etc.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ErrorFormatter
member.summary: Gets and sets the ErrorFormatter that controls the appearance of the error message in the location of the Validator control.

value.para: Users can instantiate classes and pass them or they can pass one found in the Globals.ErrorFormatters collection.
It defaults to a .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ErrorMessage
member.summary: Gets and sets the message shown by the ErrorFormatter when it determines an invalid case.

value.para: It is a string, which optionally can contain HTML. However, HTML is recommended to be used carefully. VAM attempts to allow you to separate the HTML from the error message using the ErrorFormatter and style properties for tokens on the class. This way, your error messages do not break the formatting when someone wants to change the wording.
The string can contain tokens, all uppercase one-word text enclosed in brackets. Subclasses define the supported tokens and provide translators in the client and server side. See and .
The method uses it to deliver the actual error message. GetErrorMessage can be subclassed to retrieve alternative messages and/or apply values into tokens.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ErrorMessageLookupID
member.summary: ErrorMessageLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the error message is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the ErrorMessage.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of error messages so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time. It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the ErrorMessage that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.

When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned. If no match is found OR this is blank, ErrorMessage will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMessageGroupName.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.SummaryErrorMessage
member.summary: SummaryErrorMessage is the message shown in the control when this validator has a condition that reports "failure". If blank, the ValidationSummary control uses the ErrorMessage instead.

value.para: It is a string, which optionally can contain HTML. However, HTML is recommended to be used carefully. VAM attempts to allow you to separate the HTML from the error message using style sheets and style properties for tokens on the VAMPage class. This way, your error messages do not break the formatting when someone wants to change the wording.

The string can contain tokens, all uppercase one-word text enclosed in brackets. Subclasses define the supported tokens and provide translators in the client and server side. See and . Token definitions must be identical between ErrorMessage and SummaryErrorMessage.
The method uses it to deliver the actual error message. GetSummaryMessage can be subclassed to retrieve alternative messages and/or apply values into tokens.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.SummaryErrorMessageLookupID
member.summary: SummaryErrorMessageLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the summary error message is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the SummaryErrorMessage.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of summary error messages so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time.
It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the SummaryErrorMessage that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.
When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned.
If no match is found OR this is blank, SummaryErrorMessage will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMessageGroupName.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.Group
member.summary: Gets and sets a group name for the validator. Validators are only validated when their group name matches the group name of the button that submits them.

value.para: The group name "" is a valid name and all validators, validator summary and submit buttons default to "".
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.EventsThatValidate
member.summary: EventsThatValidate determines which client side events are fired to validate.

value.para: There are two events: onchange and onsubmit. By default, both fire to validate. When you setup the validator to display an alert or other feedback on change, the message may not be needed. Use this to determine which of these events activate the message.
When set to OnChange, no server side validation is performed. Use this state to show a warning message about the data without preventing the user from submitting the page.
It defaults to All.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ShowRequiredFieldMarker
member.summary: ShowRequiredFieldMarker adds a control to the left of the error message.

value.para: Use it as a shortcut to setting up the RequiredFieldMarker. The marker is always visible.
Always place it on the leftmost validator. Otherwise, it may be pushed to the right as a validator is shown between the field and the RequiredFieldMarker.
It uses the system wide defaults found in . If you need to customize the settings, manually add a RequiredFieldMarker.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.InitFunctionName
member.summary: The client-side Initialization function is "VAM_InitValAction".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.ActionFunctionName

See the Developer's Guide for details, parameters, and examples of the Select Error Message function.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.TokenReplacementFunctionName
member.summary: TokenReplacementFunctionName is the client side Token Replacement function name that replaces runtime tokens in the error message and summary error message strings.

value.para: ValidatorAction classes that define new tokens must override this to supply their own function name. The new function should call the function of the parent ValidatorAction to handle its tokens.
See the Developer's Guide for details, parameters, and examples of the Token Replacement function.
When "", there is no token replacement.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.CanRunFunctionName
member.summary: Returns "VAM_CanRunVal" which tests the Enabler condition and the EventsToValidate property.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.IsValid
member.summary: IsValid indicates that the validator is valid or not. In other words, the condition evaluates as success or failed.

value.para: It is set by a call to . Prior to that, its value is true. You can change the value of this property manually after validation has taken place. This allows you to override the validation result, if necessary. The uses this technique.
The VAMPage.IsValid property is set to true only if the IsValid property for each validation action on the page is also set to true.

member.summary: HasValidated indicates if the method has been run.

value.para: It is initially false. Validate will set it to true.
You can still call Validate after this is true to reevaluate the validation.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction.Page
member.summary: Page optimizes retrieving the current VAMPage by limiting the number of references to get there.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MessageType
member.summary: MessageType determines the destination of the error message: Shown in the error formatter or validation summary. It is used primarily in the BaseValidatorAction. method.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MessageType.ErrorFormatter
member.summary: The error message appears in the validator control's ErrorFormatter. When this is used, the ErrorFormatter can indicate that is doesn't support the style sheet formatting that optionally encloses the tokens.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.MessageType.Summary
member.summary: The error message appears in the ValidationSummary control.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidatorAction
member.summary: ValidatorAction is the most basic subclass of . Its error message doesn't provide any customization (tokens). It can be used with any condition.

remarks.para: It offers no additional properties or methods.
It requires the user to assign a condition instance.
Programmers who create a often create this class as their ValidatorAction.

If you want a ValidatorAction that supports conditions that use the ControlIDToEvaluate property, use . If you want a ValidatorAction that supports conditions that use the SecondControlIDToEvaluate property, use .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseOneFldValidatorAction.TokenReplacementFunctionName
member.summary: The client-side Token Replacement Function is "VAM_OneFldReplToken". When you override this method, be sure your client-side function calls VAM_OneFldReplToken.

remarks.para: It replaces the "{TEXTVALUE}" token with the text value of the field.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseOneFldValidatorAction.Label
member.summary: Label provides text for the "{LABEL}" token which can appear in ErrorMessage and SummaryErrorMessage properties.

value.para: The "{LABEL}" token is intended to be replaced by the name of the field that has the error message. It usually shows the same text as the label near the field and can even use a reference to that text if its a System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label or control. It can also be entered directly into this object when there is no Label control or the text must be different.
The class offers properties to alter the text of the Label control by changing case and stripping trailing characters like colon.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseMultiConditionValidatorAction.Label
member.summary: Label provides text for the {LABEL} token which can appear in ErrorMessage and SummaryErrorMessage properties.

value.para: The {LABEL} token is intended to be replaced by the name of the a field that has the error message. The user can identify a System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label or control. It can also be entered directly into this object when there is no Label control or the text must be different.
The class offers properties to alter the text of the Label control by changing case and stripping trailing characters like colon.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LabelText
member.summary: LabelText describes the text used as a label for a field on the page. This class is used in various ValidatorAction and Validator control classes to support the "{LABEL}" tokens.

remarks.para: By itself, a label is meaningless. However, a ValidatorAction's ErrorMessage or SummaryErrorMessage can contain a token that identifies the label, like "{LABEL}". This token replacement uses a LabelText object on the ValidatorAction to build the text.
Often, users will write the label directly into the error message. The token is generally used when the error message comes from a standardized string for the site.
LabelText offers several properties to provide the text:

item.description: LabelControlID - A control ID to a label field on the page. It must be in a common or parent naming container.
LabelControl - An alternative to LabelControlID. A reference to a control that contains the label. Set it when the control is outside the naming container or parent.
Text - If assigned, its used as a label instead of LabelControl/LabelControlID.
Case - Determines if the case needs to be changed. None, Upper, Lower, Proper Noun
TrimTrailingSymbol - When true, if the label ends in any non-alpha numeric characters, they are stripped. For instance, "Label:" -> "Label".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LabelText.LabelControlID
member.summary: LabelControlID is an ID to another control that represents the label of the field. It is one of several ways to determine the text source. It can be overridden by and .

value.para: Use it when the label is in the same or any parent naming container. If assigned to an unknown controlID or one in an incorrect naming container, an exception will be thrown at runtime.
It defaults to "".
Stores its value in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LabelText.LabelControl
member.summary: Gets and sets a reference to a label control. It is an alternative to that allows the control to be anywhere on the page instead of the same naming container as the Owner control.

value.para: When assigned, it overrides any setting LabelControlID.
This can be a reference to the control anywhere on the page, not just in the same naming container.
Stores its value in .

member.exception: When the control class is not validated by the .

member.summary: Text is an alternative to using or . When assigned, it is used as the text of the label.

value.para: Use it when the label may not be clear enough or has HTML formatting that shouldn't be shown.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LabelText.TextLookupID
member.summary: TextLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the Text is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the Text.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of error messages so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time. It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the Text that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.

When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned. If no match is found OR this is blank, Text will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cLabelGroupName.
It defaults to "".

member.summary: A base class for user controls that are to be used within the portal
member.remarks: The base class provides methods and properties that make working with the control in a portal setting easier

member.summary: Overrides SaveViewState method in base class
member.returns: Object representing the viewstate that was saved

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortalUserControlBase.IsFirstLoad
member.summary: Gets whether or not the control is being loaded for the first time
member.remarks:
Because controls in the portal may be loaded after the initial postback has already occured, IsPostBack cannot be used to determine if the current load is the first time that particular control has been loaded.
IsFirstLoad uses viewstate to determine if the control was previously loaded. If a certain viewstate value is detected it means that the control must have been loaded previously to set the value, and therefore IsFirstLoad is false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.PortalUserControlBase.IsBrowserRefresh
member.summary: Gets whether or not the current page instance was created in response to a user clicking the refresh button in their browser window after doing a postback
member.remarks:
This property makes it easier to prevent events from being fired in response to a browser refresh. If the property returns true then event handling code (such as that in an button click event hanlder) should probably be bypassed to prevent unexpected behavior.
This property will only return true if IsPostBack is true. (Page refreshes that occur when no previous postback has occured are not tracked.)

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMException
member.summary: VAMException provides a class for exceptions specific to VAM that aren't covered by any of those defined in .Net.

remarks.para: Most exceptions generated within VAM use this class. System.ArgumentException and System.FormatException are used where applicable.
VAMException does not extend System.Exception. Errors are always determined only by the Message property.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of VAMException with the Message property.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage
member.summary: VAMPage defines page level properties and behaviors. Many of its properties customize the user interface.

remarks.para: One VAMPage instance gets created for each . It is defined in Globals.GetVAMPage and is stored in HttpContext.Current.Items["VAMPage"].
Due to the design of ASP.NET, when Server.Transfer is called, HttpContext.Current.Items is not refreshed. The page designer must use Globals.BeforeServerTransfer and Globals.AfterServerTransfer.
Here are the features of this class:

item.description: Maintains a list of all Action instances on this page. All Actions automatically register themselves into the page as they are created.
Between the Page's OnPreRender and Render methods, it creates all client-side JavaScript for the Actions and the page level properties.
Maintains all page level properties. The class supplies default values for most of the page level properties.
Provides the page level methods and property.
Provides the property for Redistribution Licenses.
