member.summary: fFieldStateControllers is a list of BaseFieldStateController subclasses.

value.para: They are added with (called by the constructor).

This list is created because the ValidateGroup method is called before the OnPreRender phase is run. OnPreRender causes BaseFieldStateController to add FieldStateActions and ValidateGroup needs to run those actions early.
When null, there are no FieldStateControllers.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.AddAction(Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAction)
member.summary: When an Action is constructed, it's immediate added to VAMPage through this method. Should be called as the Action is setup.

remarks.para: The object is added to .
As it reviews the Action class and its properties, it may set the following fields to true: , , or .

An Action object may be later eliminated from the Actions collection if its SetupComplete is false (the Owner did not run OnPreRender), the Owner lacks an ID (cannot access it on the client-side), or Owner.Visible is false (doesn't generate any client side HTML).

member.param: The newly created Action class associated with this page.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterWithPage
member.summary: RegisterWithPage attaches VAMPage to the instance so that the Page calls between the OnPreRender and Render stages.

remarks.para: The Page class does not actually have an event handler called between its PreRender and Render methods. We cannot ask the developer to override the page's PreRender or Render methods to call this. Instead, this implements a hack. It finds the last control in the tree and hooks onto it's PreRender event handler.
Every Action calls this from its PrepareBody method. This allows the Action to be setup and know that its enabled before calling this method.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.fRegisteredWithPage
member.summary: Flag to prevent RegisterWithPage from running multiple times.

member.summary: fForm is a reference to the HtmlForm object on the page.
member.remarks: It is captured by . If it remains null and the user wants the onReset event handler, the user must call with a reference to the HtmlForm object on the page.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.FindLastControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This recursive method finds the last control on the page that isn't an HtmlForm.

remarks.para: Called by .

We hope to find one after HtmlForm in the same Controls list. This often happens where a LiteralControl containing "</body></html>" is after the form. However, when the header has scripting or asp tags (<% %>), there is no LiteralControl. If the <body> tag has runat=server, it may be the last on the page and we cannot attach to that since its PreRender is run FIRST.
Rule: We cannot use the PreRender event of the HtmlForm or any controls list with only one control unless its below the HtmlForm or on the HtmlGenericControl with tag = "body".

member.param: The control or Page whose children being searched.
Only set to true when pParent in the HtmlForm object.
member.returns: The control found. This control will have its PreRender event attached to PagePreRegister.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.AutoRunActions
member.summary: AutoRunActions looks through the Actions collection for actions with AutoRunAction and calls DoAction on them.
member.remarks: It allows actions to do their work server side as part of setting up a page. For example, FieldStateAction needs to setup its ControlToChange so the client side page initially has the correct look.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.DefineClientSideActions
member.summary: DefineClientSideActions goes through the Actions list and prepares their client-side JavaScript.

remarks.para: It does these things:

item.description: Creates a JavaScript array called gVAMActions.
Creates a call to VAM_InitActions.
Creates JavaScript VAM objects for each action and adds it to gVAMActions.
Adds calls to VAM_UpdateOnClick for each element in fSubmitControls.
Supports InitialFocusControl with a call to VAM_SetFocus.

remarks.para: gVAMActions provides a single list for ALL actions. JavaScript will reference individual items through the indexes of the items in the array.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.DefineDisableSubmit
member.summary: Creates the client-side code used for the feature that disables submit buttons upon submission.

remarks.para: Adds each control registered with into a client-side array, gVAMSubmitIDs. The clientIDs are added into the array.

If there are no validators on the page, it sets up the onsubmit event handler to use VAM_DisableSubmit. When there are validators on the page, the VAM_TryToSubmit function calls VAM_DisableSubmit automatically.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ValidateGroup(System.String)
member.summary: ValidateGroup instructs any ValidationActions to validate (by calling DoAction). It sets and .

remarks.para: It takes a group name to validate. If pGroup is "*", it validates all.
Usually, you'll use method to retrieve the group from the hidden VAM_Group field.
It sets the state of IsValid to true when all validators evaluate their conditions to true. Otherwise, IsValid is false.
It sets HasValidated to true.

member.param: The group name of validators to validate. Pass "*" for all validators.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.Validate
member.summary: Validate validates the validators matching the group name that submitted the page.

remarks.para: This method simply calls and passes the result to .

Normally a page developer does not need to call this directly because any button registered with VAMPage (including all VAM buttons) calls ValidateGroup automatically. However, you may want to call it yourself when you need to prepare data on the page before Validate or ValidateGroup runs. You can call Validate multiple times during a post back.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.GetSubmitGroup
member.summary: GetSubmitGroup returns the group name that caused the submission. If not found (not on a post back), it returns "*" which means 'all groups'.
member.remarks: The Group Name is stored in the hidden field whose ID is "VAM_Group". The client side scripts assign it on any submit action.
member.returns: The group name

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterSubmitControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: RegisterSubmitControl makes a control's onclick event run client-side validation code in addition to whatever else it does.

remarks.para: The VAM buttons and submit controls all call this automatically. Any other submit control should call this explicitly to attach VAM's onclick code.

Microsoft's built in buttons automatically define onclick code including __doPostBack (via GetPostBackClientEvent) and Page_ClientValidate() (via the internal function System.Web.UI.Util.GetClientValidateEvent.) VAM must play well with the Microsoft controls that do this. This method must modify the client-side onclick event.

Microsoft chose to generate the onclick event code inside the Render method. It does not merge any Attributes["onclick"] code. So the user can end up with two onclick events. The browser only runs the first which is always the validation code.

We need to override this and it can only happen after Render. So we write client-side javascript into the page to modify the onclick script as the page is loaded. The function VAM_UpdateOnClick handles this.
RegisterSubmitControl's job is to set up this client-side code. pControl must have the final ClientID it will use on the client side. So make sure its ID property has its correct value.
pGroup will be used to run validators with a matching value in Group including "". You can pass pGroup = "*" to run through all validators regardless of the Group.

VAM has subclassed the following controls to call this automatically: Button, ImageButton, LinkButton, HtmlButton, HtmlInputButton, HtmlInputImage Use this when you cannot switch your button to one of the subclassed values.

member.param: The submit control to be registered.
The group name that is associated with this submit control.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterSubmitControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: RegisterSubmitControl makes a control's onclick event run client-side and optionally server-side validation code in addition to whatever else it does.

remarks.para: An overload that adds the SetupServerValidate parameter. Use this new parameter to indicate if you want to setup the Click event handler to run the Validate method. Only set it to true when calling this from Page_Load. Any later phase of page generation, including click-events, is too late.

Adds the Click event handler for these controls and their subclasses: System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button, System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton, System.Web.UI.WebControls.ImageButton, System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlButton, System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputButton, and System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputImage.
It uses to receive the click event.

member.param: The submit control to be registered.
The group name that is associated with this submit control.
When true, setup the Click event to call the event handler.
When true, you are calling this from the PreRender phase of your control or page. When false, you are calling it from the initialization or load phase of the control or page.

member.summary: Event handler for click events on any registered submit control.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ControlCausesValidation(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: Determines if pControl has a CausesValidation property and returns its value. If it does not have CausesValidation, it returns true.

remarks.para: Each of Microsoft's submit controls defines their own CausesValidation property. This knows about each of those classes and properties. In addition, it supports any control that implements .

member.param: The control to evaluate.
member.returns: The value of the CausesValidation property on the control or true.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterChildSubmitControls(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: If you have a control that has child submit controls that are not registered with VAM, use this to update all of them.

remarks.para: This calls on each submit button found in the child list of the control passed in. If you select ShallowSearch = false, it looks through all controls in the tree below the ParentControl. If you select ShallowSearch = true, it only looks at the immediate children.

This method considers the following to be submit controls including subclasses but not including VAM's own controls: System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button, System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton, System.Web.UI.WebControls.ImageButton, System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlButton, System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputButton, and System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputImage.
Note: If you have already used RegisterSubmitControl on any of the children, they will be registered twice and will setup the JavaScript twice. So avoid that.

member.param: The submit control whose children submit controls must be registered.
The group name that is associated with all of these submit controls.
When true, setup the Click event to call the event handler.
When true, you are calling this from the PreRender phase of your control or page. When false, you are calling it from the initialization or load phase of the control or page.
When true, only update the immediate children; when false, update all children in the tree.

member.summary: GetValidateGroupScript is a function for page developers that returns a string which can be used in a client-side onclick event of a button.

remarks.para: Generally buttons can use RegisterSubmitControl. But when a button is a Reset or Clear command, it never submits and fires the VAM_TryToSubmit client-side function. This returns a string that calls VAM_TryToSubmit with a group name.
For example:

member.param: The group name that is associate with the submit action.
member.returns: A JavaScript string to use with an onclick event.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterSubmitButtonToDisable(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: Adds a submit button or other control to a list that will be disabled on the client-side when the user submits. This prevents double submissions.

remarks.para: Controls are written to the client-side array gVAMSubmitIDs, by their client ID. The form's onsubmit event handler will invoke VAM_DisableSubmit().

Most browsers support the ability to disable a Button. IE supports the ability to disable a hyperlink. Most others do not. So do not expect 100% reliability when you choose something other than a button.

member.param: A button or other control to disable upon submission.

member.summary: DescribeProperties is useful for the end user to debug the property settings that they can set.

remarks.para: If you want to dump the property settings to the current page, consider using Response.Write() in your Page_Load method or add a LiteralControl to your page and assign this method's result to its text.

member.returns: A string whose format depends on the pHTML parameter.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.IsScriptBlockRegistered(System.String)
member.summary: IsScriptBlockRegistered is a user function to be called from within various DefineJavaScript() methods throughout VAM. Call it with a key name that uniquely identifies the script that you want to register. If it returns false, follow up by calling to register your script.

remarks.para: This is a wrapper around RegisterScripts.IsClientScriptBlockRegistered which itself is a replacement for System.Web.UI.Page.IsClientScriptBlockRegistered.

member.param: The unique identifier associated with the script to determine if a script with this key has already been registered.
member.returns: When true, a script with this key has already been registered.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterScriptBlock(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: RegisterScriptBlock is a user function to be called from within various DefineJavaScript() methods throughout VAM. It adds client-side script to the page, near the starting <form> tag.

remarks.para: Use when registering a script file.
This is a wrapper around RegisterScripts.RegisterClientScriptBlock and is a replacement for System.Web.UI.Page.RegisterClientScriptBlock.

First call to determine if you should call this. Then call it with a key name that uniquely identifies the script that you want to register. Your script can have or omit "<script>" tags. If they are omitted, this function will create them for you. Usually you should omit them unless you are registering a script file which always requires starting and ending script tags.
It writes the scripts just after the starting <form> tag. If you need a script written just before the ending </form> tag, call RegisterScripts.RegisterStartupScript.

member.param: The unique key associated with this script used to later prevent adding a second copy.
The script.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.RegisterScriptFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: RegisterScriptFile registers a URL to a script file on the page.

remarks.para: It basically creates the <script> tags pointing to the pURL (src=pURL). It assumes the script file is javascript.
It also guarantees that the script tag will appear above any script blocks registered with .

When referencing a file, there can be file path problems. You may need to enforce a specific absolute path from the domain root (like "/aspnet_client/MyScripts/Script.js") or if you give the user flexibility, have a specific <appSettings> parameter in the web.config file that permits customization.
You can supply a tilde (~) as the first character of the URL. It will be adjusted to include the root path to the web app if the web app is below the domain root path.

member.param: The unique key that allows you to test if this key has already been used in .
The URL to the script file.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.Current
member.summary: Current is a static property that returns the current VAMPage for this page.

remarks.para: This is the same as using Globals.Page.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.Licensing
member.summary: Assign the Licensing Key string when using a Redistribution License.
member.value:
Licensing should be assigned to the licensing string in Page_Load. This handles page specific licenses. Mostly Redistribution licenses are assigned here although any COULD use it. Other license types are encouraged to use Globals.Licensing.
The licensing string can be:
blank - trial version licenses
serial number alone - site license and redistribution license
serial number | computer name; (repeat); - single server license and development licenses
License keys are only validated at runtime.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.Actions
member.summary: A collection of all Action instances on the page.

value.para: Actions are added automatically when they are instantiated.
This list is processed between the Page's OnPreRender and Render methods to create client-side JavaScript in and let FieldStateActions initialize associated controls in .

If the Action is not run through an OnPreRender event of its Owner control, it should not be later used in DefineClientSideActions. PagePreRegister detects these actions by checking BaseAction.SetupComplete and deleting any that are are not complete or have an Owner that is Visible=false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.CultureInfo

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.Browser

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.FocusOnChange
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting to set focus to the control which caused a validation error on a client-side onchange event.

It defaults to Globals.DefaultFocusOnChange, which starts at false.

Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_FocusOnChange when there are validators on the page and the following condition is true: FocusOnChange OR ShowAlertOnChange OR (ControlErrorCssClass.Length > 0).

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.FocusOnSubmit

It defaults to Globals.DefaultFocusOnSubmit, which starts at false.

Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_FocusOnSubmit when there are validators on the page and the following condition is true: FocusOnSubmit OR ShowAlertOnSubmit OR (ControlErrorCssClass.Length > 0) || fHasValidationSummaries

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ShowAlertOnChange
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting that determines if an alert appears when a validation error occurs during a client-side onchange event.

value.para: When true, the alert is shown.
It consolidates the error messages from all invalid validator actions attached to the field that invoked the error.
It uses the property to apply formatting before and after the error messages. Messages are formatted with and .
It defaults to Globals.DefaultShowAlertOnChange, which starts at false.

Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_AlertOnChange when there are validators on the page and the following condition is true: FocusOnChange OR ShowAlertOnChange OR (ControlErrorCssClass.Length > 0).

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ShowAlertOnSubmit
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting that determines if an alert appears when a validation error occurs during a client-side submit page event.

value.para: When true, the alert is shown.
It consolidates the error messages from all invalid validator actions attached to the field that invoked the error.
It uses the property to apply formatting before and after the error messages. Messages are formatted with and .
It defaults to Globals.DefaultShowAlertOnSubmit, which starts at false.

Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_AlertOnChange when there are validators on the page and the following condition is true: FocusOnSubmit OR ShowAlertOnSubmit OR (ControlErrorCssClass.Length > 0) || fHasValidationSummaries

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ControlErrorCssClass
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets the style sheet class name assigned to a control when it is associated with a validation error. The original class is restored when no error is detected.

value.para: Style sheet changes only occur when this property contains text. It should contain a name of a style sheet defined on the page.
When this is assigned, each control will be assigned an "OrigCss" attribute with the original Class name on the server side. This allows the client side to flip back.
It defaults to Globals.DefaultControlErrorCssClass, which starts at "".

Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_AlertOnChange when there are validators on the page and the following condition is true: FocusOnChange OR ShowAlertOnChange OR (ControlErrorCssClass.Length > 0).

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.AlertTemplate
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting that places text before and after error messages shown in an alert.

value.para: AlertTemplate is used when using or .
If its blank, you will get only a list of error messages. Otherwise, use the token "{0}" in this string. It will be replaced by the error messages.
It defaults to Globals.DefaultAlertTemplate, which starts at "Please correct these errors:\n{0}".
Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_AlertTemplate when there are validators on the page.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.AlertTemplateLookupID
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting that provides an alternative to . When used, the AlertTemplate is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the AlertTemplate.

value.para: It provides localization based on the current culture.

To use it, assign a key string that represents the AlertTemplate that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string. When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned. If no match is found OR this is blank, AlertTemplate will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMiscGroupName.
It defaults to Globals.DefaultAlertTemplateLookupID, which starts at "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.AlertErrorLeadText
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting that places text before each error message shown in an alert. Use it to denote a new message. For example, "-" or "*".

value.para: AlertErrorLeadText is used when using or .
If you use a # symbol, that character will be replaced by a number that represents the error message's position in the list.
It defaults to Globals.DefaultAlertErrorLeadText, which starts at "#. ".
Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_AlertLeadText when there are validators on the page.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.AlertErrorListStyle
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a page-level setting that formats the list of error messages shown in an alert.

value.para: AlertErrorListStyle is used when using or .
When true, error messages are listed on separate lines.
When false, error messages are listed in a single paragraph style.
It defaults to Globals.DefaultAlertErrorListStyle, which starts at true.
Written to the client-side as the global gVAM_AlertListStyle when there are validators on the page.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.LabelTokenCssClass
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a style sheet class name to be used directly on any "{LABEL}" token within an ErrorMessage. (Includes "{LABEL2}", "{LABEL3}", "{LABEL4}".)

value.para: By using a style sheet this way, you don't have to embed any HTML into the error message and can easily change the style globally.
Assign a valid style sheet class name that is defined on the page. When "", no change in style is applied.
The style sheet is inserted into the ErrorMessage string on the server side using a <span class= > tag.
It defaults to Globals.DefaultLabelTokenCssClass, which starts at "".

value.para: By using a style sheet this way, you don't have to embed any HTML into the error message and can easily change the style globally.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.DefaultGroup
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets the group name that is used when the user hits ENTER on the page to submit.

value.para: In this situation, the buttons don't get their onclick event handler run. So no button applies its Group property to the submission code. So this is a fall-back. It actually only establishes an initial group on the page. Once the user clicks a button, it changes the default to that group.

A hidden field with the ID "VAM_Group" is added to the page with the value of this property. It is a hidden field because its updated when Submit buttons with different groups are invoked. Then its used to supply the server side with the group of the Submit button.
It defaults to "". This property does not use the system-wide defaults on the Globals class.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.InitialFocusControl
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a reference to a control that will get the initial focus when the page is loaded. It must be set programmatically.

value.para: JavaScript is setup on the client-side to handle this setting.
If assigned, the client-side script "VAM_SetFocus('" + InitialFocusControl.ClientID + "') is added to the startup scripts on the page.
When null, this property has no effect.
It defaults to null.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ConfirmMessage
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a string to show in a confirmation message box when the user submits the page. The MessageBox includes OK and Cancel buttons where Cancel stops the submission process while OK continues.

value.para: When this is "", no alert is shown.
The alert appears based on the group being submitted. It must match .
This value is assigned to the client-side global gVAMConfMsg when this property is not "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.ConfirmMessageGroup
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets the group name that must match the submit command before showing the message box.

value.para: If its "*", it matches all groups.
This value is assigned to the client-side global gVAMConfMsgGrp when this property is not "".
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.CustomSubmitFunctionName
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets the name of a client-side function that is called when the page is submitted for validation. It allows you to extend the submission logic.

value.para: This client-side function is called after the ConfirmMessage and before the fields are validated to allow you to insert your own pre-page submission logic.
The function must take one parameter, the group name, which is a string. It must return a boolean value where true means continue and false means stop.
When this property is "", no client-side function is defined.
This property is assigned to the client-side global gVAMCstmSubmitFnc when the value isn't "".
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.UseOnResetEventHandler
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets a flag that determines if the page generation also installs the onreset event on the Form. If it does, is called when the page is generated.

value.para: When true, the onreset event handler is installed.
It defaults to true (usually harmless to have it installed.)

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.PostValidationUpdateScript
member.summary: Page-level property. Gets and sets JavaScript that will be executed after validation occurs on the client-side.

value.para: This property's primary intent is to allow you to run client-side code that relocates absolutely positioned elements after validator error messages have caused the page to reposition non-absolutely position elements.
You can enter any JavaScript statements you want into this string. Your string will be executed by using the JavaScript eval() function.
This function may be called even if nothing visually changed on the page.
When assigned, this string is assigned to the client-side global gVAMValUpdFnc.
It defaults to "". (Does not use Globals because scripts are usually very page specific.)

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.IsValid
member.summary: IsValid indicates if the page's validators are all valid or not. This is usually called in a post back event handler before taking an action on the page like saving the data.

value.para: IsValid returns true when the page's validators all return valid for the group name that was submitted.
It is initially true prior to a call to . After Validate() is properly reflects the state of validators.
Check to determine if Validate has run.
If you are using an and set its IsValid property to false, VAMPage.IsValid will automatically be set to false as well.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage.HasValidated
member.summary: HasValidated indicates if the method has been run.
member.value: It is initially false. Validate will set it to true. You can still call Validate after this is true to reevaluate the validation.

member.summary: Used by the BaseCondition.OverrideClientSideEvaluation property.

remarks.para: These values determine if the CustomEvalFunctionName is assigned to the "VAM_EvalAltCS" function. When not set to No, it is and the client-side gets a Mode property with one of these values:

item.description: When its a new page, 1 to avoid showing the error.
On post back, when Hide it hides the error when the field is changed or the page is submitted.
On post back, when HideOnSubmit, it hides the error when the page is submitted but keeps it on change events PRIOR to submitting. It hides the error message on change events after submitting.

member.summary: On post back, hide the error message on a submit event. Leave it on a change event unless it is already hidden.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ConditionEventArgs
member.summary: ConditionEventArgs is passed to the . It is used by which has no fields to pass.

remarks.para: Microsoft's design for ServerValidateEventArgs is the basis for this. In it, it passes the fields text value in the Value property and gets your result in the property IsMatch.

Since CustomCondition lacks fields of its own, there is no Value property. However, there is a property. The IsMatch property should only be set to true or false if the condition can be evaluated. Otherwise set the property to true. (It defaults to false.) This allows you to indicate that your function only works when all conditions are setup for it. For instance, don't evaluate when the text box is blank.

Set to false when the condition evaluation ran but field values did not match the condition.
If the condition evaluation cannot run due to values that aren't supported by the condition, set to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ConditionEventArgs.CannotEvaluate
member.summary: The developer of the ServerCondition event handler must set this to true when it determines that values in the field aren't supported by the condition.

value.para: For example, if you require two text boxes to contain numbers, this should be true when either text box is blank (detectable by RequiredTextValidator) or non-numeric (detectable by DataTypeCheckValidator).
It defaults to false.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.MetaControls.Attributes.DropDownListMetaControlAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to declare the need for a preference or setting to be displayed as a DropDownList
member.remarks:
This attribute can be applied to either a portlet (a class that inherits from PortletBase) or an application (a class that inherits from PortalApplicationBase).
It will be used by the framework to automatically generate the appropriate preferences or settings overlay that allows the user to enter the data for that preference or setting using the control specified.
This information can then be retrieved by using the various preference and settings domain objects in the framework. They can also be accessed by using the Preferences or Settings property of the PortletBase and PortalApplicationBase classes.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.DataTypeTextBoxAction
member.summary: The Action class for DataTypeTextBox controls.

remarks.para: DataTypeTextBoxAction provides a client-side only interface which operates only on TextBoxes. TextBoxes may be datatype specific, such as allow integers, dates or currency values. We've already got objects to read the contents of a text box and determine that its type is valid or not. The DataTypeCheckCondition handles that determination.
This class takes the final action of reformatting the text after its found to be valid. Numbers, currency, dates and times are obvious candidates for such reformatting while strings really don't fit.

The is assigned a VAMTypeConverter through the constructor. The VAMTypeConverter provides a client-side method, CSConvertToFunctionName, which takes the result of the CSConvertFromFunction and reformats it.
The overall client-side action looks like this:

Run the DataTypeCheckCondition's CSConvertFromFunction. If the result is valid, run the CSConvertToFunction to get a string and assign it back to the control associated with the DataTypeCheckCondition.
See the Developer's Guide for an overview.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDataTypeTextBox
member.summary: BaseDataTypeTextBox is the base class for all DataTypeTextBox controls.

remarks.para: BaseDataTypeTextBox is a subclass of that uses the Action class to manage the data type and reformatting rules. Subclasses must provide the that defines the datatype and reformatting rules by overriding the method.
When is true, it adds an onkeypress event handler to the client-side with the "VAM_KeyFilter" function. The characters to allow in the textbox come from the method.

It provides two methods to get and set the data of the text box: and . They interact with the generic System.Object type. Subclasses must define properties of the correct data type that utilitize these methods, typecasting the generic object.
See the Developer's Guide for an overview.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDataTypeTextBox.GetKeyFilter
member.summary: GetKeyFilter is used to support keyboard filtering of the text box.

remarks.para: OnPreRender adds an attribute called "KeyFltr" with the string supply by this method and uses it in the client-side "VAM_KeyFilter" function.

When blank, there is no filtering. Otherwise, each character of this string is a valid character for the field. Any other character is ignored. It doesn't affect movement and editing keys like arrows, page up, delete, backspace, and tab.
All letters should be uppercase as keystrokes will be case insensitive.
Include digits, letters, space and punctuation in this string. It should use international formatting as needed from VAMPage.Current.CultureInfo.
It defaults to "".
Aside from calling the ancestor, it does the following:

item.description: If UseKeyboardFiltering is true, it adds the attribute "KeyFltr" with the string from GetKeyFilter.
Creates the Action using and transfers properties from the control instance to the Action before running .
If the Text is blank, it assigns the value of ValueWhenBlank.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseDataTypeTextBox.SupportClientSideLookupByID
member.summary: SupportClientSideLookupByID allows JavaScript programmers to get several client-side functions: VAM_FindAOByID, VAM_GetDTTBValue, VAM_SetDTTBValue, and VAM_FormatDTTBValue.

value.para: Use the client-side function VAM_FindAOById to search for the action that matches the clientID you specify. That function will return null if not found. Use the Action object to modify it, such as changing the Enabled property.

Use the client-side function VAM_GetDTTBValue to get the native data type value from the textbox. Pass the ClientID of the textbox. It returns a native data type (int, double, etc) or null if it could not convert the data.

Use the client-side function VAM_SetDTTBValue to set the native data type value to the textbox, following the culture formatting you assigned to the textbox. It returns true if the value successfully was assigned.
When this property is true, two things happen:
1. The ID is written as a property, CID, into the control.

2. If the Enabled property is false, normally no code is written to the client side. This is overridden and code is generated so users can toggle the enabled property. Note that client-side code is NEVER generated when the browser doesn't support it or the EnableClientScript property is false.

example.para: This shows how to use the VAM_GetDTTBValue and VAM_FormatDTTBValue functions. The page has two DataTypeTextBoxes and a <span> tag that will show the results of adding both textboxes together. This is JavaScript code.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SCheckBoxList
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the CheckBoxList control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.PickPropertyTypeForm
member.summary: PickPropertyTypeForm is used by the UITypeEditor .

remarks.para: It allows the user select a BaseCondition subclass from a list. The list is generated from ConfigFile., which is itself from the VAM.config and Custom.VAM.config files.

The user can also select a "None" button to return with no condition. Only open this dialog box when there is no condition selected to get an initial value. Use it to select a different condition from the .
Use the Condition property to exchange the BaseCondition class that is being edited. If you select None, Condition will return null.

member.summary: Provides basic security for portlets that should only be useable by privlidged users.
member.remarks: This is done by exposing a global operation that is then checked before the portlet is rendered. member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup
member.summary: StringLookup defines global events, properties and methods used by the String Lookup System.

remarks.para: The String Lookup System provides various string properties with the method to translate a LookupID value into the associated text. Underlying StringIDLookup is an event handler that does the translation. Unless the event handler is hooked up, no translation is provided.
This class supplies several predefined event handlers, for resource and database storage. Users can write their own event handler too.
See the User's Guide for details on setting up the String Lookup System.
This class includes:

item.description: The event handler method used for lookups from resource files.
The event handler method used for lookups from a database.
Properties to configure the ResourceManagerLookupHandler and DatabaseLookupHandler. The ability to read those properties from custom.VAM.config in .
The event , which is called by the StringIDLookup method.
Constants for the lookup ID categories: , , .

remarks.para: It is called by .

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup.StringIDLookup(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: StringIDLookup translates a LookupID into a string.

remarks.para: It uses to handle the translation. If OnLookupString is null, the LookupID is "", or no match is found, it returns the default value.

member.param: The key to lookup.
The default value supplied by the user on a property of the object.
Segregates strings into different groups. This allows multiple resource files or other ways to separate data in a query.
member.returns: The looked up string or the default value.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup.Configure
member.summary:
Configure is called when the system is being initialized to establish
and all the properties that support it.

remarks.para: It is called by when fConfigured is false. That means it is called after Application_Start. It will not overwrite any setting made during Application_Start.
It uses custom.VAM.config's <StringLookup> section to determine values:

item.description: DesignModeOn - If in design mode, this must be true for the rest of the system to load. Set to false when the datasource isn't available or cannot be accessed in design mode.

MessageResXFile - The name of the ResX file compiled into the ResourceAssembly that contains the Message group. It should not contain the "resx" extension. If not supplied, "VAMMessages" is used. Internally, the resource name is ResourceAssembly.Name.ThisName.

LabelResXFile - The name of the ResX file compiled into the ResourceAssembly that contains the Label group. It should not contain the "resx" extension. If not supplied, "VAMLabels" is used. Internally, the resource name is ResourceAssembly.Name.ThisName.

MiscResXFile - The name of the ResX file compiled into the ResourceAssembly that contains the Misc group. It should not contain the "resx" extension. If not supplied, "VAMMisc" is used. Internally, the resource name is ResourceAssembly.Name.ThisName.
SqlConnectionString - The MSSql database connection string used with the DatabaseLookupHandler.
OleDbConnectionString - The OleDb database connection string used with the DatabaseLookupHandler.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup.GetResourceManager(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: GetResourceManager returns an instance of ResourceManager if possible.

remarks.para: It gets the name of the resource file by first looking in the <StringLookup> section of the custom.VAM.config file using the ConfigName. If not found, it uses DefaultName. Then it creates a and assigns it to . It may return null when no resource file matches in the web app.

member.param: The key within the <StringLookup> section of the custom.VAM.config file that contains the file name.
The default file name when the custom.VAM.config file does not have an entry for the ConfigName.
member.returns: A reference to the System.Resources.ResourceManager that contains the resources requested or null if it could not load.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup.DatabaseLookupHandler(Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LookupStringHandlerArgs)
member.summary: DatabaseLookupHandler is used to lookup data from a database using the stored proc: VAMLookupString.

remarks.para: The stored proc must be defined by the user. It has the following parameters:

item.description: Full culture name
One of these strings: "MESSAGE", "LABEL", "MISC"
The lookupID string
OUTPUT PARAMETER. The resulting text

remarks.para: The stored proc must return 1 if it returns localizedtext. 0 if not.
This method supports Sql and OleDb connections.
It also has a caching mechanism to avoid too many lookups using HttpContext.Current.Cache. Cache entries have the name: StringGroup + CultureName + LookupID. Entries in the cache expire in 1 hour.

member.param: Supplies the StringGroup, LookupID and Default.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup.ResourceAssembly
member.summary: ResourceAssembly is a reference to the assembly containing resources for use by the . assigns it to the assembly . Users can override this in Application_Start.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StringLookup.ResAssemblyName
member.summary: The file name of the assembly containing the resources.

remarks.para: It does not include the path to the file. The file must be in the web application's \bin folder.

Resources must declare a namespace that matches the ResAssemblyName. For example, if resources are in VAMMisc.resx file, when you compile it into the assembly "MyVAMResources.dll", the namespace to this resource must be "MyVAMResources.VAMMisc.resources".

member.summary: LookupStringHandler is a delegate used by the StringLookup. method to translate a string ID into a string.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LookupStringHandlerArgs
member.summary: LookupStringHandlerArgs is the event arguments for events.

remarks.para: It has these properties:

item.description: LookupID - The key used to lookup a string
Default - A string already defined by the user used when localization systems work that way
StringGroup - A name to identify a group of strings. Allows separate lists of LookupIDs for different types. ErrorMessage and SummaryErrorMessage both use the term "MESSAGE".
CultureName - The same value as in Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentCulture.Name. The expected culture of the string.
Found - When true, a string was found and returned
Result - The string to return to the caller

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ProgrammersValidator
member.summary: ProgrammersValidator doesn't have any particular ValidatorAction or Condition. You establish them, either through the constructor or by direct assignment to the Action property and its Condition property. This validator is best used programmatically.

remarks.para: Select this validator control when you have created your own Condition subclass and do not want to build a Validator subclass too. This allows you to programmatically instantiate your condition, a BaseValidatorAction subclass (usually ) for the Action, and the ProgrammersValidator. You would assign any of the Condition's properties programmatically too.
The ProgrammersValidator can be added to the ASP.NET page. In doing so, you must assign the Condition to the ValidatorAction and the ValidatorAction to the ProgrammersValidator.Action property.
If you instantiate the ProgrammersValidator, it can be added to the child controls list of a System.Web.UI.PlaceHolder or any other control that accepts child controls.
See the Developer's Guide for strategies on using this class.

example.para: Suppose you have created the condition "MyNamespace.MyCondition" based on a with its one new property, "MyProperty" (an integer). In this example, you use a ProgrammersValidator and ValidatorAction with it. The ProgrammersValidator has already been added to the ASP.NET page with the ID "ProgrammersValidator1".
example.code:
Dim vCond As MyNamespace.MyCondition = New MyNamespace.MyCondition() ' establish the properties vCond.ControlToEvaluate = TextBox1 vCond.MyProperty = 2 Dim vVA As Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidatorAction = New Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidatorAction(vCond)
ProgrammersValidator1.ValidatorAction = vVA

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseOneFldValidator.Label
member.summary:
Label provides text for the {LABEL} token which can appear in
and properties.

value.para: The {LABEL} token is intended to be replaced by the name of the field that has the error message. It usually shows the same text as the label near the field and can even use a reference to that text if its a System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label or control. It can also be entered directly into this object when there is no Label control or the text must be different.
The class offers properties to alter the text of the Label control by changing case and stripping trailing characters like colon.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RequiredTextValidator
member.summary: RequiredTextValidator supports the . RequiredTextCondition determines if the ControlToEvaluate field that has a textual value is considered blank (matches the property). When its not blank, the condition evaluates as "success".

remarks.para: See the User's Guide for an overview of using this Validator.
This condition supports any control with a as they all can return a textual value.
The user can define one or more values for an unassigned state using the property. UnassignedValues can be compared case sensitive or insensitive with the property.
Uses the property to determine if a blank field allows spaces or not.
The ValidatorAction is .
It exposes these properties of RequiredTextCondition: , .
There are no additional properties to expose on RequiredTextValidatorAction.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RequiredTextValidator.UnassignedValues
member.summary: UnassignedValues is the text representing the unassigned state. When the control's value matches this value, the condition evaluates as "failed".

value.para: Matching may be case sensistive or insensitive based on .

This string supports multiple items that reflect the unassigned state. They must be separated by a pipe (|). For example, a text box is unassigned when either blank or "Enter a value" is present. Use "|Enter a value". (The part prior to the pipe is an empty string.)
Lead and trailing spaces are removed on each item within the UnassignedValues.
It defaults to "".
Transferred to Condition.UnassignedValues in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RequiredTextValidator.UnassignedCaseInsensitive
member.summary: UnassignedCaseInsenstive determines if the property uses a case insensitive match or not.

value.para: When true, its case insensitive.
It defaults to true.
Transferred to Condition.UnassignedCaseInsensitive in .

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RequiredListValidator
member.summary: RequiredListValidator supports the . RequiredListCondition determines if the following controls have a selection that differs from an unassigned state: subclasses of (ListBox, DropDownList, RadioButtonList, and CheckBoxList) and .

remarks.para: See the User's Guide for an overview of using this Validator.
There is an property that allows the user to define an item that when selected is still the unassigned state. It defaults to 1 which indicates no selection is the unassigned state.
NOTE: CheckBoxLists do not support the UnassignedIndex property. They are unassigned by having no checkboxes marked.
ListBoxes with multiple selections are supported. The condition evaluates as "success" when any selected item matches the UnassignedIndex.

If you define a series of checkboxes or radio buttons without using CheckBoxList or RadioButtonList and want to know if there is any selection, use a with an AND operator and a associated with each checkbox/radiobutton.
The ValidatorAction is .
It exposes these properties of RequiredListCondition:
There are no additional properties to expose on RequiredListValidatorAction.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegexValidator
member.summary: RegexValidator supports . RegexCondition compares a string from any field supporting to a Regex expression. If Regex returns a match, the condition evaluates as "success".

remarks.para: Set the property to the control and the expression with .
See the User's Guide for an overview of using this Validator.

The regular expression must be compatible with both .Net and JavaScript. JavaScript's RegEx syntax is a subset of .Net so that description should be used. See:
http://devedge.netscape.com/library/manuals/2000/javascript/1.5/reference/regexp.html#1193136
One of the more powerful features of Regular expressions is the OR condition, using the | operator. For example, you can match US and internation phone number strings: (USRegEx)|(IntRegEx)
The ValidatorAction is .
There are no additional properties to expose on RegexValidatorAction.
It exposes these properties of RegexCondition: , , .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegexValidator.Expression
member.summary: Expression is a Regular Expression that is valid for both JavaScript and .Net RegEx parsers.

value.para: This condition evaluates as "success" when the Regular Expression parser matches the control to this expression.
When left blank, the condition evaluates as "cannot evaluate".

The regular expression must be compatible with both .Net and JavaScript. JavaScript's RegEx syntax is a subset of .Net so that description should be used. See:
http://devedge.netscape.com/library/manuals/2000/javascript/1.5/reference/regexp.html#1193136
One of the more powerful features of Regular expressions is the OR condition, using the | operator. For example, you can match US and internation phone number strings: (USRegEx)|(IntRegEx)
Transferred to Condition.Expression in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegexValidator.CaseInsensitive
member.summary: CaseInsenstive determines if the matching uses a case insensitive match.

value.para: When true, it is case insensitive.
It defaults to true.
Transferred to Condition.CaseInsensitive in .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegexValidator.Multiline
member.summary: Multiline changes the meaning of ^ and $ so they match at the beginning and end, respectively, of any line, and not just the beginning and end of the entire string.

value.para: It defaults to false.

Note:Many browsers do not support this option during client-side regular expression parsing. Only set this to true when you are certain your user's browsers will support it. Browsers found to support it include IE for Windows and Netscape 6+. IE for Mac and Netscape 4 definitely do not. Others have not been tested by PeterBlum.com.
Transferred to Condition.Multiline in .

member.summary: Returns false. You cannot change the ValidatorAction.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CompareToStringsValidator.Items
member.summary: Items is the collection of strings which will be compared against the contents of the textbox. It can optionally be set by DataBinding()

value.para: This property must be assigned at least one string although it really should be used with two or more because the CompareToValueCondition is better to comparing one string.
There are two ways to establish the contents of this list:
This property is a collection. Add a string by calling the Add method like this: Add("string value")

Use databinding. Establish the , , and properties. You don't need to call the DataBind() method because simply setting these properties will databind when the Validator control is in its OnPreRender stage.
Provides the UITypeEditor .

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.TextLengthValidator
member.summary: TextLengthValidator supports . TextLengthCondition compares the length of a text field to a minimum and maximum number of characters.

remarks.para: See the User's Guide for an overview of using this Validator.
Establish the minimum with and maximum with .
This condition supports up to two textboxes in and . When both are used, the total characters of the two are compared to the Minimum and Maximum.
While <input type='text' /> fields support a maxlength, <textarea> elements do not. This condition is very useful to limit the entry in multiline TextBoxes.
The ValidatorAction is .
There are no additional properties to expose on TextLengthValidatorAction.
There are no additional properties to expose on TextLengthCondition.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseMultiConditionValidator.Label
member.summary: Label provides text for the {LABEL} token which can appear in ErrorMessage and SummaryErrorMessage properties.

value.para: The {LABEL} token is intended to be replaced by the name of the a field that has the error message. The user can identify a System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label or control. It can also be entered directly into this object when there is no Label control or the text must be different.
The class offers properties to alter the text of the Label control by changing case and stripping trailing characters like colon.
Transferred to ValidatorAction.Label in .

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.IgnoreConditionValidator
member.summary: IgnoreConditionValidator provides a validator without its own condition. Instead, you assign the property directly.

remarks.para: You could use the CustomValidator to develop your own condition. However, that validator requires you to put your validation logic in an event handler, often separate from where you'd like the code.
Use this validator when you simply want to set the IsValid property false in code that you write in a post back event handler, which is run long after all validators on the page have been evaluated.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LocalizableLabel
member.summary: LocalizableLabel extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.Label to use the String Lookup System of VAM.

remarks.para: Within VAM, each text property that needs localization has a partner property that ends in "LookupID". The user assigns a key to this LookupID and VAM runs the "String Lookup System" to translate the LookupID into the correct string.
In this class, the Text property now has the TextLookupID property as its localization partner. When TextLookupID is blank or the String Lookup System can't translate it, the Text property is used.

The advantage of this control is that a web interface designer can assign the key whereas often other systems require some code to assign the translation. For example, when using resources, you'd usually code a line that does:
This control uses string group StringLookup.cLabelGroupName.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.LocalizableLabel.TextLookupID
member.summary: TextLookupID provides an alternative to Text. When used, the error message is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database to use as the Text.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of error messages so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time.
It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the Text that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.
When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned.
If no match is found OR this is blank, Text will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cLabelGroupName.
It defaults to "".

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ChangeTypePropertyGridForm
member.summary: A form that provides a PropertyGrid to edit an object.

remarks.para: This Windows Form is used by Visual Studio.Net's design mode from within several UITypeEditors. It provides a PropertyGrid that will edit whatever object you pass in through the property.
When DialogResult is OK, the Instance property is updated with changes entered by the user.
It offers a "Select Another" button which opens the defined by the subclass. This lets the user select another instance or select "None" to end the process without an instance.
Only open this dialog box when the Instance property can be set (is not null).

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.MetaControls.Attributes.TextBoxMetaControlAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to declare the need for a preference or setting to be displayed as a TextBox
member.remarks:
This attribute can be applied to either a portlet (a class that inherits from PortletBase) or an application (a class that inherits from PortalApplicationBase).
It will be used by the framework to automatically generate the appropriate preferences or settings overlay that allows the user to enter the data for that preference or setting using the control specified.
This information can then be retrieved by using the various preference and settings domain objects in the framework. They can also be accessed by using the Preferences or Settings property of the PortletBase and PortalApplicationBase classes.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.EditCommandColumn
member.summary: A subclass of the DataGrid's that makes registers its buttons with VAM.

remarks.para: The System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataGrid creates standard buttons using DataGridLinkButton and Button classes in EditCommandColumn. Instead of replacing them, this subclass simply registers them with VAM using VAMPage.RegisterChildSubmitControls. It also hooks up their Click event handler to call VAMPage.ValidateGroup.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SPlaceHolder
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the PlaceHolder control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SListBox
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the ListBox control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts
member.summary: RegisterScripts is a wrapper around Microsoft's Page.RegisterClientScriptBlock and Page.RegisterStartupScript methods that allows ordering, grouping under one <script> tag and avoids a bug where the order is lost after 10 scripts are added.

remarks.para: RegisterScripts is a collection of objects. Users add to the collection by calling to see if the item exists and to add.
It contains a number of static methods to operate on two instances of this class: for ClientScriptBlocks and StartupScriptBlocks.

Most of the time, the user should call the static methods that parallel those on the System.Web.UI.Page class: ,
, and .

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.fNextOrder
member.summary: fNextOrder provides a sequential ordering of RegisteredScripts. Each time a RegisteredScript instance is added to the list, increment this and use its value in the RegisteredScript.Order property.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.IsRegistered(System.String)
member.summary: IsRegistered tests the Key passed in to determine if that key is already registered. If not, you can call Register.
member.param: The key name. The user invents unique key names for each script.
member.returns: True when already registered; false when not. Call Register when it returns false.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.Register(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds the Script with the specified Key into the collection.
member.remarks: Any script blocks with the same pKey parameter values are considered duplicates. Call IsRegistered first and call this only when that method returns false. to avoid unnecessarily running code that creates the scripts.
member.param: The Key name. The user invents unique key names for each script.
The script. If it contains the <script> tags, set AddScriptTags to false.
When true, the user wants script tags to be added automatically.
Provide additional ordering. The higher then number, the lower the script appears on the page. The default group is 0.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.Add(System.Object)
member.summary: Add a RegisterScript object to the collection.
member.remarks: You should call to add to the collection.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.WriteScripts(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: WriteScripts asks this instance to transfer its scripts into pScriptBlock in the order they were added. No formatting is added except a carriage return if the last character of a script is not one. All formatting comes from the user.
member.remarks: This is called as the page finishes its OnPreRender method to create a single string that is passed to Page.RegisterClientScriptBlock or Page.RegisterStartupScript by the caller. The data is properly ordered and contains the any <script> tags around those that didn't supply it.
member.param: Append the scripts to this stringbuilder.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.GetClientScripts(System.Web.UI.Page)
member.summary: GetClientScripts gets the instance of this class for ClientScriptBlocks.
member.remarks: It keeps the collection in HttpContext.Current.Items["[SystemName]_ClientScripts"] When first used, the collection is created.
member.param: The current Page. Used to hookup an event handler.
member.returns: The RegisterScripts instance that stores the ClientScriptBlocks.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.GetStartupScripts(System.Web.UI.Page)
member.summary: GetStartupScripts gets the instance of this class for StartupScriptBlocks.
member.remarks: It keeps the collection in HttpContext.Current.Items["[SystemName]_StartupScripts"] When first used, the collection is created.
member.param: The current Page. Used to hookup an event handler.
member.returns: The RegisterScripts instance that stores the StartupScriptBlocks.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.LinkToPage(System.Web.UI.Page)
member.summary: LinkToPage hooks up the TransferToPage event handler to the last control on the page's Control list's OnPreRender event. This assures us that TransferToPage is run during OnPreRender but after all controls WITHIN the <form> have run.
member.remarks: WARNING: This method has been replaced for VAM to simply return. VAM calls the TransferToPage method from the VAMPage.PagePreRegister method.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.FindLastControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This recursive method finds the last control on the page that isn't an HtmlForm.
member.remarks: WARNING: This method is not used in VAM's implementation.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.PrepareControl(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: PrepareControl is designed for custom controls to call before using the Register methods. WARNING: This method is not used in VAM's implementation.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.TransferToPage(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: TransferToPage is called to write the scripts to the page using the Page.RegisterClientScriptBlock and Page.RegisterStartupScript methods.

remarks.para: These functions will get ALL scripts in a single call so they maintain their order.

member.param: Ignored. Can pass null.
Ignored. Can pass null.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.AfterServerTransfer
member.summary: AfterServerTransfer should be called in the Page_Init method of a page that is called from Server.Transfer.
member.remarks: Server.Transfer doesn't clean up elements we've added to HttpContext.Current.Items on the page that calls Server.Transfer. This resets the scripting for new information of this page.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.IsClientScriptBlockRegistered(System.Web.UI.Page,System.String)
member.summary: IsClientScriptBlockRegistered is used to check that a script with the key name specified is not already registered in the ClientScriptBlocks collection.
member.remarks:
Returns true when it's already registered. Only use
after this returns false.
member.param: The page instance.
The key to check.
member.returns: True when the key is already present. False when it is not. Only call RegisterClientScriptBlock when this returns false.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.RegisterClientScriptBlock(System.Web.UI.Page,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: RegisterClientScriptBlock adds a script to the ClientScriptBlock collection.

remarks.para: The script parameter can have any thing valid for an HTML page. It will be added at the top of the <form> block.
Any script blocks with the same Key values are considered duplicates. Call first and call this only when that method returns false to avoid unnecessarily running code that creates the scripts.

member.param: The page instance.
The key to uniquely identify this script.
The script.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.RegisterClientScriptBlock(System.Web.UI.Page,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: RegisterClientScriptBlock adds a script to the ClientScriptBlock collection with an option to enclose the script in <script> tags.

remarks.para: The script parameter can have any thing valid for an HTML page. It will be added at the top of the <form> block.
Any script blocks with the same Key values are considered duplicates. Call first and call this only when that method returns false to avoid unnecessarily running code that creates the scripts.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.Enabled
member.summary: Enabled determines if scripts are collected or transferred to the page immediately.

value.para: When true, they are collected until the page has prerendered its controls.
When false, they are transferred to the page right away.
This is kind of an on/off switch so you can write your code one way and turn off the added layer as needed.
Since it is static, it affects all threads running this object. So don't turn it on/off for each page being generated. Only set it during Application_Start.
It defaults to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.SystemName
member.summary: HttpContext.Current.Items holds several elements associated with the page. The strings for these must be unique. SystemName defines a prefix to the names we use.

value.para: It can generally remain unchanged unless you want to group information separately between different systems. (Such as two separate control products that don't prefer to intermix their code.)
VAM sets this to "PBDC.VAM"

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisterScripts.ScriptSeparator

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisteredScript.Group
member.summary: Group provides the ability to group related scripts so one group can appear above or below another. Within a group, items are sorted by the Order property which is the order of entry by default. The lower the value, the higher it appears on the page. Zero is the default group and is usually considered the top. However, negative values are legal.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.RegisterScriptsClasses.RegisteredScript.Order
member.summary: Order is the order within a Group. By default, it is the order entered into the list. The lower the value, the higher it appears on the page. Zero is the default and is usually considered the top. However, negative values are legal.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SLabel
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the Label control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals
member.summary: The Globals class provides a number of static methods and properties used throughout VAM. Some are used internally. Others are intended to the user.
member.remarks:
There are several categories of methods and properties:
returns the current instance of VAMPage completely assigned default values.
VAMPage defaults - numerous properties which match those on the VAMPage class, with the addition of "Default" to the property name. The user can set them up in Application_Start or in the custom.VAM.config file.
Other defaults - some defaults that don't have corresponding properties on VAMPage, such as the default strings for RequiredFieldMarker and RequiredFieldDescription.
provides access to the data retrieved from the VAM.Config and custom.VAM.config files.
Methods to register script files into the page.
Methods to interact with the ASP.NET: Find by ID, create a style string, create a web color string.
Paths to VAM and Appearance folder.
Localization engine.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.cValidatorsAndMoreFolderName
member.summary: The root folder name for VAM's licenses and scripts. It is "VAM". It is under the web application folder by default.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.cDefaultAppearancesPath
member.summary: The default path to the Appearances folder. It is "~/VAM/appearance/".

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetVAMPage
member.summary: GetVAMPage returns a VAMPage instance for this page request.

remarks.para: The instance is kept in HttpContext.Current.Items["VAMPage"]. The Items collection is recreated with each new page (except after Server.Transfer). When Items["VAMPage"] is null, a new instance is created and initialized with values from the properties on Globals. The very first time this is called, it calls to load the contents of the two VAM.config files.
When a page is called from Server.Transfer, use and to correctly update this VAMPage instance.

member.returns: VAMPage instance.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.BeforeServerTransfer
member.summary: BeforeServerTransfer must be called immediately before any call to Server.Transfer that goes to another page with VAM controls.
member.remarks:
It removes the current VAMPage instance in preparation for the destination page. The destination page will install new actions into the new VAMPage instance (created automatically when missing) before the
method is called. Be sure to call AfterServerTransfer in the Page_Load method of the desintation page.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.AfterServerTransfer(System.Web.UI.Page)
member.summary: AfterServerTransfer updates VAMPage class after a call to a new page from Server.Transfer. Use it on any page that contains VAM controls and is called by Server.Transfer.

remarks.para: Server.Transfer switches to a new System.Web.UI.Page instance without updating HttpContext.Current.Handler. So we cannot detect that the VAMPage already in use is no longer valid.
The user manually calls this after to Server.Transfer to invalidate the current VAMPage. The call belongs in the destination page's Page_Load method.
Caller must also call .

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.DesignModeVAMPage
member.summary: DesignModeVAMPage holds a reference to the VAMPage instance during design mode. HttpContext.Current.Items normally holds it but that object is not available in design mode.
member.remarks: Assigned by during design mode. This one instance of VAMPage will be shared between all web forms in design mode.
