member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.RegisterScriptFile(System.Web.UI.Page,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: RegisterScriptFile adds a <script> tag with src= attribute set to the filename supplied. The file must be in VAM's script folder.

remarks.para: It avoids duplicate entries by using RegisterClientScriptBlock which uses a key which you pass in pRegisterName.
The file name gets a path from the "VAM_ScriptVirtualPath" key in the <appsettings> section of web.config:
If that key is not defined, it gets the default path from this assembly's ScriptFilePathAttribute. That is "\VAM\#_#_#"

member.summary: ApplyAppPath looks for the ~ character at the start of the URL. If found, it is replaced by Request.ApplicationPath or, in design mode, the ADME UrlToWebApp.
member.remarks: Microsoft has defined the tilde (~) to do this elsewhere and this carries the idea along.
member.param: The original URL
member.returns: The URL, whether modified or not.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.FindID(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: Finds the control ID passed in and returns its ClientID or returns "" if not found.

remarks.para: It searches the naming container of the Control passed in. If not found, it goes up through parent naming containers until it finds a match or runs out of parents.
It will never find a match to sibling or child naming containers.

member.param: A control whose naming container is where the search starts.
The Control ID to find.
member.returns: The ClientID of the control found or "" if not found.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.FindControlByID(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: Finds the control associated with ID passed in and returns the control instance or null if not found.

remarks.para: It searches the naming container of the Control passed in. If not found, it goes up through parent naming containers until it finds a match or runs out of parents.
It will never find a match to sibling or child naming containers.

member.param: A control whose naming container is where the search starts.
The Control ID to find.
member.returns: The control instance of the control found or null if not found.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.FindChildControlByID(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: FindChildControlByID only looks for a control whose ID is in the immediate child list of the ParentControl passed in.

remarks.para: It doesn't use FindControl which will look in the nested control hierarchy, wasting time.

This also avoids a design mode problem in VS.NET 7.0 and .Net Framework 1.0: In design mode, when there is label the tag doesn't get added into the Page's control list until you switch from design view to HTML view and back When it finally gets added, it creates the child label within it. Unfortunately, there is a Label1 already in the control list.

member.param: The control whose child Controls list is searched for the ID.
The ID to match to one of the child controls.
member.returns: The matching child control or null.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.PrepJavaScriptString(System.String)
member.summary: Replaces single quotes with the string \' so strings can embed single quotes.

remarks.para: JavaScript only supports single quotes embedded in strings when they are preceded by a slash. This converts strings to support that. It should be applied on any property that is written in a DefineProperties method if the user is allowed to add a single quote into that property.

member.param: The original string to be modified.
member.returns: The string with quotes updated.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetWebColor(System.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: GetWebColor converts properties into a string that is compatible with DOM based color attributes.

remarks.para: When adding a color to an HTML style string, such as style='background-color:green', the Color structure's naming scheme doesn't always return a name that is compatible with the browser's definition of the color name. This prepares the correct strings.

item.description: Color.Empty = ""
Color.LightGray -> LightGrey
Color.IsNamedColor -> Color.Name
All the rest: Color.ToArgb

member.param: The System.Drawing.Color structure to convert.
member.returns: The HTML compatible string representation of the color.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetStyles(System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style)
member.summary: GetStyles returns a string containing elements of the in a format that can be placed into the HTML attribute style=''.

remarks.para: It contributes what's between the ''.

MS chose to make Style.AddAttributesToRender() use an HTMLTextWriter. That method is better suited for a Render method than for adding styles to a string. ErrorFormatters need a string representation of the style as they create their HTML in the OnPreRender phase of control generation.

member.param: The System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style to convert into an HTML compatible style='' attribute list.
member.returns: A string representation of the ControlStyle for use within the style= attribute of a tag. It does not include the outer quotes.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetStyleValue(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: GetStyleValue looks up a key in a control's Style property ().

remarks.para: While this may appear to be a simple action, there are two situations this addresses:
1. pControl can be a WebControl, HtmlControl or other. This gets the style by the class.
2. The CssStyleCollection class performs a case sensitive lookup. We must have a case insensitive lookup.

member.exception: If the Control is not subclassed from WebControl or HtmlControl.
member.param: The control whose style will be searched for the key.
The key to locate withing the style collection.
member.returns: If the key is found, it returns the value associated with that key. Otherwise it returns null.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetControlName(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: GetControlName returns a name for the control for display in error messages.
member.remarks: If ID is assigned, it is returned. Otherwise, it returns "[" + pControl.GetType().FullName + "]".
member.param: The control whose name is desired.
member.returns: The control's ID or its type.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetResolvedDataSource(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: GetResolvedDataSource is used by DataBound controls to convert their DataSource property (either IEnumerable or IListSource) into an IEnumerable.
member.remarks: Follows a standard documented in "Developing Microsoft ASP.NET Server Controls", page 428 although its implemented as a static method to allow reuse. This really emulates the private class System.Web.UI.DataSourceHelper which has the same static function. WHY MUST IT BE PRIVATE?
member.param: The DataSource associated with a DataSource property.
The value of a DataMember property. It determines a table in ADO.NET DataSources.
member.returns: A reference to the data or null if no datasource provides an IEnumerable.

member.summary: ConvertUrlWithSiteRoot takes a URL and returns a URL that may be corrected for the Web Application path or have its path to the Appearance folder changed.

remarks.para: When the URL passed starts with a match to and the user has supplied the web.config key "VAM_AppearanceVirtualPath", it substitutes the VAM_AppearanceVirtualPath string for the cDefaultAppearancesPath.
Otherwise it calls to replace the tilde (~) with a path to the web app path.

member.param: The original URL.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.GetDefaultAppearancePath

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.ConvertToStringByDataType(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: ConvertToStringByDataType provides conversion between a value of a particular datatype and its string formatted by the VAMTypeConverter associated with the datatype.

remarks.para: This is useful in string properties like RangeCondition.Minimum/Maximum and CompareToValueCondition.ValueToCompare, which uses the datatype's VAMTypeConverter to translate the string into its native value.
Here, you are passing the native value and getting back the correctly formatted string.

This function is intended for page developers who need to setup the string properties of RangeCondition.Minimum/Maximum and CompareToValueCondition.ValueToCompare. For example, if the RangeCondition is using the DataType="Date", the user will assign a date string to the Minimum property. First they create a DateTime structure with the date. Then pass it here to get back the correctly formatted date string.

member.param: The name of a DataType as defined in the VAM.config and custom.VAM.config files. It is used to identify a VAMTypeConverter instance to use for converting the value.
The value that will be converted. It is in a native format for the datatype, such as Int32 for "Integer" DataType.
member.returns: String version of the value. It may return "".
member.exception: Throws exceptions when it cannot convert or the DataType string is not found.

If TrueBrowser.SupportsJavaScript1_2 is false and the ErrorFormatter is AlertImageErrorFormatter, it switches to the error formatter in if that is not null.
If TrueBrowser.SupportsClassName is false and the ErrorFormatter.CssClass has a value, it merges the ErrorFormatter.ControlStyle with .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.Licensing
member.summary: Defines the Licensing Key for Trial, Single Server, and Site Licenses.

value.para: Licensing should be assigned to the licensing string in Application_Start.
The licensing string can be:

item.description: blank - trial version licenses
serial number alone - site license
serial number | computer name; (repeat); - single server license and development licenses. The computer name is the production server computer name.

value.para: Licenses are only validated at runtime.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.Config
member.summary: Config returns the instance that contains data from the current web application's VAM.config and custom.VAM.config files.

value.para: If not already loaded, it loads via and establishes the default data type name in as the first VAMTypeConverter in ConfigFiles.DataTypes. (If no VAMTypeConverters are found, DefaultDataType is "String".)
Once loaded, each reference to Config will determine if the config files have been changed and reload when that happens.

member.exception: If it cannot load VAM.config or custom.VAM.config.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.ConfigFilePath
member.summary: ConfigFilePath gets and sets the file path used to get the ConfigFile path.

1. If there is an <appSetting> key in the web.config file for "VAM_ConfigFilePath", it uses that string.
2. Otherwise, use "[web application]\VAM\"
Uses ADME to get these values in design and runtime modes.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.ControlHookupMethods
member.summary: Provides access to using the currently loaded ConfigFile class in .

remarks.para: The Control Hookup Method allows a control to define multiple onchange or onclick events that fire it. For example, if the control contains several textboxes, it would override this to hookup those textboxes.

When defined, VAM installs the HUCtrlFnc property on the client side representation of the condition object and the JavaScript function VAM_HookupControl redirects to your Control Hookup Method to hook up its controls to the onchange or onclick events.

The software also checks the VAMTypeConverter.GetControlHookupMethod for a match to the control. If neither supply a string, no HUCtrlFnc property is specified on client side representation of the condition object and the default hookup method is used.
See the Developer's Guide for a description of the Control Hookup Method and an example.
VAM defines its support for CheckBoxList and RadioButtonList in this collection because they need access to their child check button controls.

Each Control Hookup Method is declared in the <ControlHookupMethods> section of the VAM.config and custom.VAM.config files. To add your own control, add it to the <ControlHookupMethods> section of the custom.VAM.config file. (The preferred method is to declare a VAMTypeConverter with the function name returned in its VAMTypeConverter.GetControlHookupMethod method.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.AppearancePath
member.summary: AppearancePath holds an alternative virtual path to the Appearance folder.

value.para: That folder is normally in ~/VAM/Appearance. The user can supply the "VAM_AppearanceVirtualPath" key in the <AppSettings> section of web.config to provide an alternative.

This is a virtual path. When assigned, any property referencing ~/VAM/Appearance/ will replace its path with AppearancePath in . This allows all factory supplied defaults to follow the VAM_AppearanceVirtualPath without the user editing the properties.

Defaults to the method .
See the User's Guide for more on using this event.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.ErrorFormatterWhenNoJavaScript
member.summary: ErrorFormatterWhenNoJavaScript is used by the DefaultAdjustVAToBrowser method when TrueBrowser.SupportsJavaScript1_2 is false. It returns an instance of an alternative errorformatter.

value.para: The caller will clone the returned instance before using it.
If it returns null, it indicates that the current error formatter is acceptable.
It defaults to null.
If the user assigns this to a , they should be aware that it will use a different amount of space.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.ErrorFormatterWhenNoTooltip
member.summary: ErrorFormatterWhenNoTooltip is used by the DefaultAdjustVAToBrowser method when TrueBrowser.SupportsTooltip is false. It returns an instance of an alternative errorformatter.

value.para: The caller will clone the returned instance before using it.
If it returns null, it indicates that the current error formatter is acceptable.
It defaults to returning an because JavaScript is usually available when the tooltip (Title= attribute) isn't.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.Globals.NoStyleSheetErrorFormatterControlStyle

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.AdjustValidatorActionToBrowser
member.summary: AdjustValidatorActionToBrowser is used by the Globals. property to allow the action to be modified based on the current browser in .

remarks.para: The idea is to scale down gracefully. Here are typical choices to scale down:

item.description: When TrueBrowser.SupportsClassName is false, apply non-style sheet font info to the ErrorFormatter.ControlStyle property.
When TrueBrowser.SupportsTooltip is false, switch from TooltipImageErrorFormatter to another ErrorFormatter.
When TrueBrowser.SupportsJavaScript1_2 is false, switch from AlertImageErrorFormatter.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ScriptFilePathAttribute
member.summary: ScriptFilePathAttribute is an which stores a string containing a file path to a VAM script file within the scripts folder.

remarks.para: The Globals.RegisterScriptFile method uses this attribute.
This was designed to allow new builds to update the version number within the AssemblyInfo.cs file instead of updating source code files.
It adds a lead and trailing slash if you omit them. So if the file is located at /VAM/1_0_0/my.js, this should be "/VAM/1_0_0/" or "VAM/1_0_0".

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ScriptFilePathAttribute.fPath
member.summary: Stores the resulting path assigned in the constructor.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ScriptFilePathAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that sets the Path.
member.param: The virtual path to a script file folder.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.TrueBrowser
member.summary: TrueBrowser indicates which browser is really running.

remarks.para: should handle this but the user can set a fake browser in the page's clientTarget. VAM absolutely needs to know the real browser here.
You can access the current TrueBrowser instance on VAMPage.Browser.

This class identifies the browser type, version, and operating system, much like HttpBrowserCapabilities. It also identifies a variety of features that VAM needs to know about the browser to set up the HTML and JavaScript from the server side.
See the User's Guide for details on using this class.

member.summary: GetTrueBrowser creates or retrieves an existing TrueBrowser object for the current browser identified by Page.Request.ServerVariables["HTTP_USER_AGENT"].

remarks.para: This method provides caching of TrueBrowser objects. Only one is created for each unique HTTP_USER_AGENT per application start.

member.summary: This is the cache of TrueBrowser objects created by . It holds one TrueBrowser object for each unique HTTP_USER_AGENT that has requested a page.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.TrueBrowser.ReliableScripting
member.summary: Some browsers may support JavaScript 1.2 and some of DHTML or DOM, but simply are too buggy or unreliable to support VAM's client-side scripting. When true, the browser runs VAM's scripts reliably.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.TrueBrowser.SupportsJavaScript1_2

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary
member.summary: BaseValidationSummary is an abstract base class for developing validator summary controls. It defines the behaviors for validator summaries but does not generate HTML, except for the outer tag. It leaves innerHTML generation to subclasses.

remarks.para: Behaviors include

item.description: property
property
property
and RelatedControl properties
property
Support for setting up an hyperlink from the error message to the field that established it

remarks.para: It builds the outer frame the control within an <DIV> tag, using WebControl to define the style properties.
One or more can be placed on a page. When the page is submitted and there are validation errors, the summary may appear, filling its body with a list of the error messages.

When subclassing, add properties for formatting, such as header, footer and body formatting. Then override to create the HTML for server side rendering and
to generate properties that appear in a client-side representation of the ValidationSummary. ValidationSummary has a full client-side mode. However, it turns off on browsers that don't support setting the InnerHTML.
There are two client-side functions which must be defined:

item.description: FormatListItem named in the property
GetInnerHTML named in the property

remarks.para: The client-side representation of Validation Summary objects are placed into the gVAM_ValSummary array.
See the Developer's Guide for an overview and examples.

member.name: F:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.fSupportsClientSideB
member.summary: Set by OnPreRender. When true, client side code is supported through both and TrueBrowser.SupportsClientSideValidationSummary.

remarks.para: This control is simply a <div> tag with inner text that varies. The server and client side both may fill in the inner text.
Server side: When there is a validation error on postback for a matching group, build the inner text using .
Client side: When there is a validation error on the client side, the PostValidation functions will update all validation summarys defined in the gVAM_ValSumIDs array.
The client side needs a number of attributes to run. They are setup with .

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.MatchGroup
member.summary: Determines if the submitted group name matches the validator.

remarks.para: MatchGroup returns true when on post back and the submitted group matches the group in . Group can be a pipe delimited list of multiple groups.
If the submitted group is "*", this always return true.
Returns false otherwise.

member.returns: True when the submitted group matches the Group property or is "*". False otherwise.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.GetErrorText(Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage)
member.summary: Builds all of the inner HTML for the ValidatorSummary.

remarks.para: Subclasses must define this to create a string that contains all the HTML shown in the ValidationSummary. Always test VAMPage.IsValid and return a string for both true and false cases. Usually when IsValid is false, it returns an empty string.

To show individual Validator error messages, it should detect all those whose IsValid=false and match the submitted group. It can get the error message from the Validator.SummaryErrorMessage or Validator.ErrorMessage property (if SummaryErrorMessage is blank.)
This is called from OnPreRender. At this point, the ValidatorAction objects of each validator should be in VAMPage.Actions.
See the Developer's Guide for details and an example.

member.param: The current VAMPage object. It contains the Actions collection with ValidatorActions among them.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.GetDesignModeText
member.summary: GetDesignModeText builds the control's text for design mode and returns a string containing the HTML that is shown in the ValidationSummary.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.ApplyHyperlink(System.String,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction)
member.summary: ApplyHyperlink returns a string containing hyperlink HTML around the error message of a single Validator control.
member.remarks:
Each error message should be retrieved from the Validator either from the SummaryErrorMessage or ErrorMessage. It should already have its tokens replaced. Pass it here and it will get wrapped in an <a> tag that calls the javascript function VAM_SetFocus(pFieldID).
If the browser doesn't support client side code or SetFocus, it returns the original string. Used by subclasses.
member.param: The error message to embed in the hyperlink.

The ValidatorAction instance that supplied the error message. Its Condition will be used to determine the control that will get focus. It will always use the first control (determined by Action.Condition.GetControl(0)).
member.returns: The error message. If possible, it is enclosed in the <a> tag to establish a hyperlink.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.DefineJavaScript(Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage)
member.summary: DefineJavaScript creates whatever JavaScript that is used by this ValidationSummary. It should define JavaScript functions or load a file.

remarks.para: It is passed the current VAMPage class which has two methods that make registration easy:
- Call VAMPage.IsScriptBlockRegistered before registering to determine if the script was written by another instance of this class.
- If its not registered, call VAMPage.RegisterScriptBlock or VAMPage.RegisterScriptFile.

member.param: Current VAMPage object.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.GetClientSideObject
member.summary: GetClientSideScriptObject defines the client-side object that represents the properties and methods of a ValidationSummary.

remarks.para: It is called from VAMPage after all controls are registered and prepared for output. Generally, you extend the method to add new properties.
Defines the property "ValSumID" to contain the ClientID of the ValidationSummary control.

member.returns: A string that is compatible with JavaScript to build a JavaScript object. It has the format "{property1,value1;property2,value2}".

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.DefineProperties(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: DefineProperties adds any attributes to the client-side ValSum object to build the inner HTML of this control. It basically maps all of the properties to attributes. Designed to be subclassed to introduce new properties.

remarks.para: Call the methods and to install properties into the pJavaScript stringbuilder.

item.description: FormatListItemFunctionName
GetErrorTextFunctionName
AutoUpdate
Group (can be pipe delimited)
RelatedControl.ClientID
InvisiblePreservesSpace
HyperLinkToFields

member.summary: fFirstProperty is used by AddComma to avoid writing a comma at the beginning of the properties list.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.AddComma(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: AddComma should be called prior to every property being added. It will add the comma unless its the first property (determined by fFirstProperty).

remarks.para: This method is called internally from and . You only call it if you add text to the StringBuilder within without using these other functions.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.RegisterValue(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.String,System.String)

remarks.para: RegisterValue is an overloaded method.
The pJavaScript property gets the following text appended:
[,]PropertyName: 'Value'
Call this method from your overridden method.

member.param: Append the property to this stringbuilder.
Defines the name of the property to add to the client side validation summary object.
The string for the value.

method.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.RenderAtDesignTime
member.summary: Called by the to form the design time HTML.

remarks.para: While TagKey specifies <DIV>, Html32TextWriter converts to a table. We depend on it to be a <DIV> because client side code assumes it is. If the browser doesn't support a <DIV>, we aren't going to support client side code in the first place. So force it to be a <DIV> by forcing the write to be HtmlTextWriter.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.Group
member.summary: Group is the group name to which this ValidationSummary is associated.

value.para: Submit buttons are assigned group names, including "", "*" and a name. The button group must match this value or match "*" to show this validation summary.

One ValidationSummary can support multiple groups by providing a pipe delimited list of group names. For example: "Group1|Group2". Lead and trailing spaces around each group name will be ignored and can be used for formatting.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.AutoUpdate
member.summary: AutoUpdate allows an already visible ValidationSummary to keep updating its list as the user changes fields until all the errors are gone (and the summary is hidden).

value.para: Initially, the validation summary is hidden. It gets shown when the user submits the page. From that point on, including after a post back, the validation summary will update.
It defaults to false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.InvisiblePreservesSpace
member.summary: InvisiblePreservesSpace determines if the ValidationSummary takes up space on the page when its invisible.

value.para: When true, space is not preserved. The style is set to visibility:hidden with no change to the display style.
When false, space is preserved. The style is visibility:hidden;display:none.
When the control becomes visible once again, the display style is restored to its original value.
It defaults to false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.EnableClientScript
member.summary: EnableClientScript determines if the validation summary updates itself using client side scripting.

value.para: When false, its server side only. When true, it will use client side scripting unless the browser doesn't support the client side scripting. (See TrueBrowser.SupportsClientSideValidationSummary.)
It defaults to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.RelatedControlID
member.summary: RelatedControlID allows you to set up another control that you use with the ValidationSummary. That control should be shown and hidden as the ValidationSummary is.

value.para: Typical usages:
1. An enclosing box with additional formatting that wasn't built into this validator, such as images along the sides.
2. A label that also appears on the page, saying "Fix the errors".
When "", no related control is setup. Alternatively, the user can assign the RelatedControl programmatically.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.RelatedControl
member.summary: Gets and sets a reference to a control that will be shown and hidden along with the Validation Summary. It is an alternative to that allows the control to be anywhere on the page instead of the same naming container as the ValidationSummary control.

value.para: When assigned, it overrides any setting RelatedControlID.
This can be a reference to the control anywhere on the page, not just in the same naming container.

member.exception: When the control class is not validated by the .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.RelatedControlConnection
member.summary: Gets the class that maintains the ID and Instance storage used by and properties.
member.value: A ControlConnection also validates the control that is referenced by its contents.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.HyperLinkToFields
member.summary: HyperLinkToFields creates hyperlinks on each error message. When clicked, the focus is moved to the first field that supports that error message.

value.para: When true, it is on.
Browsers that don't support the DOM/DHTML function SetFocus will not use this.
It defaults to false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.GetInnerHTMLFunctionName
member.summary: The client side requires a GetInnerHTML function whose name is defined here.

value.para: This is an abstract method. It must be subclassed.
See the Developer's Guide for a description, parameters, and an example of the GetInnerHTML function.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.FormatListItemFunctionName
member.summary: FormatListItemFunctionName defines the name of the client-side Format List Item function that formats an error message in the validation summary.

value.para: If it returns "", no function is defined and error messages are omitted but the overall ValidationSummary is drawn.
This is an abstract method. It must be subclassed.
See the Developer's Guide for a description, parameters and an example of the Format List Item function.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.Visible
member.summary: Since the control shows and hides itself based on error messages, it is inappropriate to have a Visible property. Normally Visible=false turns off a control from generating its HTML. In this control, the Enabled property makes more sense. It is not being used anyway. So Visible will actually reflect the values of Enabled.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidationSummary.Enabled
member.summary: Make Enabled toggle the Visible property to turn it on and off.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary
member.summary: ValidationSummary implements the BaseValidationSummary to be similar in style to Microsoft's ValidationSummary control, only with many enhancements.

remarks.para: See the User's Guide for an overview on using this control.
Here are key features and differences with Microsoft's control:

item.description: There are no ShowSummary and ShowMessageBox properties. This control only handles showing a summary on the page. VAMPage.ShowAlertOnSubmit is the equivalent of ShowMessageBox.

The property is used to allow multiple ValidationSummarys show error messages appropriate to a group. When the user hits a Submit button, the group on that submit button must match the value of this group property or this summary will be ignored. One ValidationSummary can support multiple groups by defining a pipe delimited list of group names. (This feature is defined in BaseValidationSummary.)

The format of the error messages starts with the same options: List, BulletedList, and SingleParagraph. However, each of these has additional support properties to extend the formatting. List can have a lead string like a dash. BulletedList supports all types of <ol> and <ul> tags. SingleParagraph can have text to separate each message.
still handles the text before the list. provides text after. Both support the String Lookup System for localization.
The DisplayMode has a None state to hide the list.

The property sets up a hyperlink on each error message that sets focus to the field that generated the error. (Requires the browser to support SetFocus function.) (This feature is defined in BaseValidationSummary.)
While the control has a style sheet, , the error messages section can override this with its own style sheet, .
Error messages come from BaseAnyValidator.SummaryErrorMessage, which supports tokens and on-the-fly customization.
The ForeColor isn't set to Red. Instead, the CssClass is set to "VAMValSummaryText".
Once the summary is shown, it stays on screen with static information until you click Submit again. The property allows it to update itself as validators change their state.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.GetErrorText(Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage)
member.summary: Formats the entire control's inner text with optional header, body (the error messages) and footer.

remarks.para: It builds a single string containing HTML that represents the header (from ), the body (from invalid validator error messages), and the footer (from ).
It uses a StringBuilder to gather the text. The StringBuilder is passed to some of the methods it calls to allow them to add text to it.
See the Developer's Guide for a code example of how this method is implemented.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.SetMessageStartFormatting(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: SetMessageStartFormatting adds text that precedes the list of error messages.

remarks.para: Its first element is HeaderText + HeaderSeparator. Then if DisplayMode needs something else, its added.
For DisplayMode = None, it adds nothing else.
For DisplayMode = BulletList, it adds the opening UL or OL tag with type determined by .
For DisplayMode = List, it adds the opening SPAN tag.
For DisplayMode = SingleParagraph, it adds the opening P tag.
For all except DisplayMode = None, it adds the HTML attributes 'class=' for and 'title=' for .
It sets in preparation for use in .

member.param: Add the text to this string builder.

member.remarks: It writes the value in that was setup in .
member.param: Add the text to this stringbuilder.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.ApplyListElementFormatting(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: ApplyListElementFormatting adds the formatting around the individual error message dictated by DisplayMode.

remarks.para:
When DisplayMode is List, it adds and before and
after.

When DisplayMode is BulletList, it adds
  • before and
    • after.
When DisplayMode is SingleParagraph, it adds before except on the first error message.
Use to insert any HTML that must procede the lines.
Use to insert any HTML that must follow the lines.

member.param: The error message text to be formatted.
A count of the error message's position in the list. Starts at 0.
member.returns: The formatted error message.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderText
member.summary: HeaderText is text that appears before the list.

value.para:
If assigned, it will automatically add a
or   between it and the list, depending on .
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderTextLookupID
member.summary: HeaderTextLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the HeaderText is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database..

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of headers so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time. It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the text that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.
When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned.
If no match is found OR this is blank, HeaderText will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMiscGroupName.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderImageURL
member.summary: HeaderImageURL places a graphic image in the header along with the header text.

value.para: The formatting depends on . In most cases, it forms a table separating the image from the text.
When blank, this property and HeaderElementPositions are both ignored.
You can use the tilde (~) character at the beginning of the text to be replaced by the absolute path to the web application root folder. For example, "~\VAM\Appearance\myimage.gif".
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderElementPositions
member.summary: HeaderElementPositions determines how the is positioned relative to the .

value.para: It may insert the image within the text or build a table.
Not used when HeaderImageURL is blank.
It defaults to ValidationSummaryHeaderElementPositions.ImageLeft.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderTextHorizontalAlign
member.summary: HeaderTextHorizontalAlign is the horizontal position of the .

value.para: It is only used when HeaderText is assigned. When there is no , this still creates a one cell table unless its set to NotSet.
It defaults to HorizontalAlign.NotSet.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderImageHorizontalAlign
member.summary: HeaderImageHorizontalAlign is the horizontal position of the image in the header.

value.para: It is only used when is assigned and is not set to ImageBeforeText and ImageAfterText.
It defaults to HorizontalAlign.NotSet.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderTableVerticalAlign
member.summary:
HeaderTableVerticalAlign is the vertical position of the
and within table cells.

value.para:
It is only used when both HeaderText and HeaderImageURL are assigned and
forms a table for these elements.
It defaults to VerticalAlign.NotSet.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderImageColumnWidth
member.summary: HeaderImageColumnWidth is the minimum width of a header column containing an image.

value.para: It is used when is set to Left or Right.
Images larger than the width always cause the browser to widen the column.
Use values showing either pixels or percentages.
It defaults to "10%".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.HeaderCssClass
member.summary: HeaderCssClass is a style sheet class name that is applied to the header.

value.para: If the header is enclosed in a table, the user can assign a border to this to enclose the header.
If left blank, the style defaults to the parent's style (CssClass and the various font attributes on this control).
It defaults to "VAMValSummaryHeader".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.FooterText
member.summary: FooterText is text that appears after the list.

value.para:
If defined, it will automatically add a
between it and the list.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.FooterTextLookupID
member.summary: FooterTextLookupID provides an alternative to . When used, the FooterText is looked up from another source, such as a resource file or database.

value.para: This allows you to define a common set of footer texts so the programmer doesn't uniquely define them each time. It also provides localization based on the current culture.
To use it, assign a key string that represents the text that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.
When you are using the default Resource Manager system of VAM, it looks at the Name field of the ResX file for a match. The Value field of that row is returned.
If no match is found OR this is blank, FooterText will be used.
This property uses the StringGroup of StringLookup.cMiscGroupName.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.FooterCssClass
member.summary: FooterCssClass is a style sheet class name that is applied to the Footer.

value.para: If the Footer is enclosed in a table, the user can assign a border to this to enclose the Footer.
If left blank, the style defaults to the parent's style (CssClass and the various font attributes on this control).
It defaults to "VAMValSummaryFooter".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.FooterHorizontalAlign
member.summary: FooterHorizontalAlign determines if the is placed in a <TABLE> or not.

value.para: When in a table, it determines the horizontal alignment.
When HorizontalAlign.NotSet, the text is not in a table. Otherwise, it is in a table whose width is 100% of the enclosing <DIV> and this specifies the alignment of the contents.
It defaults to HorizontalAlign.NotSet.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.DisplayMode
member.summary: DisplayMode determines how the list of error messages is formatted.

value.para: It defaults to ValidationSummaryDisplayMode.BulletList.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.ListLeadText
member.summary: ListLeadText is used when is set to ValidationSummaryDisplayMode.List. Its value precedes each error message.

value.para: Use it to add formatting that differs from what is offered by the HTML tags <ol> and <ul>.
If you want to show an image, use . When ListLeadImageURL and ListLeadText are both assigned, the image appears first.
It defaults to blank.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ValidationSummary.ListLeadImageURL
member.summary: ListLeadImageURL places a graphic image in front of each error message when is set to ValidationSummaryDisplayMode.List.

value.para: If is also assigned, the image appears first.
You can use the tilde (~) character at the beginning of the text to be replaced by the absolute path to the web application root folder. For example, "~\VAM\Appearance\myimage.gif".
It defaults to "".

member.summary: BulletListType is used when is set to ValidationSummaryDisplayMode.BulletList. It determines the style of the bullets, using either <ul> or <ol> with a specific type attribute.

value.para: It defaults to BulletListType.Disc.

To use it, assign a key string that represents the text that you want. This key will be used to search your data source for the correct string.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.MetaControls.Attributes.TextAreaMetaControlAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to declare the need for a preference or setting to be displayed as a Text Area
member.remarks:
This attribute can be applied to either a portlet (a class that inherits from PortletBase) or an application (a class that inherits from PortalApplicationBase).
It will be used by the framework to automatically generate the appropriate preferences or settings overlay that allows the user to enter the data for that preference or setting using the control specified.
This information can then be retrieved by using the various preference and settings domain objects in the framework. They can also be accessed by using the Preferences or Settings property of the PortletBase and PortalApplicationBase classes.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.CustomizationPortlet
member.summary: The base class for all portlets that will be used to customize the site.
member.remarks:
There are 3 customization portlets. Each of the customization portlets is responsible for altering a specific type of object.
CustomizePagePortletUsed to customize a page and its context. The user can access this by clicking "Customize this Page..." on the page that they wish to customize.
CustomizePortletPortletUsed to customize a portlet (occurance). The user can access this by clicking the customize icon in the upper right corner of the portlet titlebar for portlets that are customizeable. A portlet is considered customizable if it returns true from an accessor call to the CanCustomize property of the portlet.
CustomizeSitePortletUsed to customixe a the entire site, and includes thigls like editing the layout creating new contexts and other things.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.CustomizationPortlet.LoadPortletView(System.String)
member.summary: Loads a Portlet View from it's file name
member.param: The Portlet to load
member.returns: Object of type PortletViewBase

member.summary: Gets and sets the id of the object that this customization portlet will customize

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.CustomizationPortlet.CanCustomize
member.summary: Always returns false, indicating that the customization portlets cannot be customized!

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.CustomizationPortlet.State
member.summary: Always returns PortletState.Default

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.CustomizationPortlet.DisplayPortletHelp
member.summary: Always returns false

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.CustomizationPortlet.Title
member.summary: Gets the default text of "Customize" to be used for the title text of the portlets. Other configuration portlets like the Page customization portlet will override this to provide information about the object that they are customizing.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.MetaControls.Attributes.CheckBoxListMetaControlAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to declare the need for a preference or setting to be displayed as a CheckBoxList
member.remarks:
This attribute can be applied to either a portlet or an application (a class that inherits from PortalApplicationBase).
It will be used by the framework to automatically generate the appropriate preferences or settings overlay that allows the user to enter the data for that preference or setting using the control specified.
This information can then be retrieved by using the various preference and settings domain objects in the framework. They can also be accessed by using the Preferences or Settings property of the PortletBase and PortalApplicationBase classes.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SDropDownList
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the DropDownList control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter
member.summary: VAMTypeConverter provides a description of tools available to convert between a string and a "native data type". It supplies conversion methods on the server side and defines JavaScript functions to handle the client side.

remarks.para: On the server side, Microsoft has defined the classes to handle most conversion. The base class, VAMTypeConverter, retrieves the TypeConverter for the .Net type that you are converting. If your type does not have a TypeConverter, you have to override the and methods.

On the client side, VAM defines an object oriented methodology to install JavaScript functions that convert between text and the native data type. Since the Condition's evaluation function needs to convert text to string, it installs a method reference to the function defined for the data type that the user selects in the DataType property. The VAMTypeConverter supplies that function name in .

Conversion is often influenced by culture information. These classes use the VAMPage.CultureInfo property to identify the culture rules. They pass the relevant parts to the client-side representation of the Action or Condition objects for use with the client-side conversion functions.

Native data types also need to support comparison methods to determine equals, not equals, less than, etc. The Condition evaluation functions use the comparision methods. On the server side, when the data type implements the , it automatically handles comparisions. Otherwise, you must supply a class that implements in . On the client side, VAM supplies a comparision function for JavaScript native types like int, bool, and string. If you create a unique type, supply a JavaScript function and identify its name in .
The DataTypeTextBoxes () use the methods to convert from native data type to string.
See the Developer's Guide for extensive details in creating VAMTypeConverters.

VAMTypeConverters are associated with the DataType property of any validator and condition. You can add VAMTypeConverters to the Properties Editor for the DataType property by adding them to the custom.VAM.config file. Use the Import VAM Classes application to install your VAMTypeConverters. All VAMTypeConverters defined in VAM.config and custom.VAM.config are available in Globals.DataTypes.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.GetTypeConverter
member.summary: GetTypeConverter returns an instance of the that converts between strings and the desired native data type.

remarks.para: It calls TypeDescriptor.GetConverter(DataType) to create it.
Subclass if you don't define a value for the property or it doesn't have a TypeConverter.
You don't need to supply a TypeConverter if you override both the and methods.

member.returns: A TypeConverter that converts between strings and the desired native data type.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.ConvertFrom(System.Object)
member.summary: Converts a string into the native data type.

remarks.para: By default, it uses the method. It provides the VAMPage.CultureInfo to the conversion process. The TypeConverter is retrieved from .
When creating the native data type, it should apply culture specific formatting from VAMPage.CultureInfo.
This method should anticipate that conversion will fail: the string cannot be converted into the native data type. It must return null if it could not convert. It should not throw an exception.

member.param: The string to convert to the native data type.
member.returns: The native data type or null if it could not convert.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.ConvertTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Converts a native data type object into a string.

remarks.para: By default, it uses the method. The TypeConverter is retrieved from .
When creating the string, it should apply culture specific formatting from VAMPage.CultureInfo. The default TypeConverter class does not.
This method should anticipate that conversion will fail: the native data type cannot be converted into a string. It must return null if it could not convert. It should not throw an exception.

member.param: The native data type to convert to a string .
member.returns: The string or null if it could not convert.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.Internationalize(System.String)
member.summary: Internationalize reformats the original string using CultureInfo.

remarks.para: This is used when showing tokens in error messages. Tokens that get their values from properties on the Validator have their original value entered as a string in the local culture of the web server. This prepares the string to the culture of VAMPage.CultureInfo.
This class uses and to do the job. If ConvertFrom returns null (the string couldn't convert), it returns "???".
Subclass may determine there is no internationization needed and return the original value.

member.param: The original string that needs to be internationalized.
member.returns: The internationalized string or "???" if it could not be converted.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.TestThirdPartyControl(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: TestThirdPartyControl determines if the control passed in is a specific control class which is supported by a subclass's method.

remarks.para: It is called when is true.
It should return true if pControl matches the desired control and false if not.
BaseOneFieldCondition.GetVAMTypeConverter uses this to switch from the VAMTypeConverter defined in the DataType property of a Condition to the VAMTypeConverter that returns true in this method.

ValidationPropertyControlConnection.IsValidControl returns true when the control it is validating causes this to return true. This allows all conditions and validators that support the to automatically support third party controls.
See the Developer's Guide for an overview of implementing VAMTypeConverters for custom controls.

member.param: The control to determine if this VAMTypeConverter supports it.
member.returns: When true, the control is supported. When false, it is not. This class always returns false. Override to support your own control.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.GetControlValue(System.Web.UI.Control,System.Boolean)
member.summary: GetControlValue returns an object representing the data value of the control passed in.

remarks.para: There are three possible results:

item.description: When the data can be converted, return the value as a native data type.
When the data cannot be converted because its format is invald, return null.
If there is no data to convert, throw an Exception.

remarks.para: For example, if converting a string to an Int32, if the string is blank, throw an exception. If it is "ABC", return null. Otherwise, return an Int32.

This class assumes the control supports the
and calls the static method BaseCondition.GetControlTextValue with both parameters. Subclass to support controls that do not support ValidationPropertyAttribute.
See the Developer's Guide for an overview of implementing VAMTypeConverters for custom controls.

member.param: The control whose data value you are retrieving.
When true, it strips leading and trailing spaces on the value if the value is a string.
member.returns: The value. It should be the native data type for this VAMTypeConverter such as Int32, double, or DateTime. If it cannot convert, return null.
member.exception: If there is no data to convert.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.GetControlHookupMethod(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: GetControlHookupMethod allows a subclass that supports a third party control to establish a Control Hookup Method on the client-side.

remarks.para: The Control Hookup Method allows a control to define multiple onchange or onclick events that fire it. For example, if the control contains several textboxes, it would override this to hookup those textboxes.

When defined, VAM installs the HUCtrlFnc property on the client side representation of the condition object and the JavaScript function "VAM_HookupControl" redirects to your Control Hookup Method to hook up its controls to the onchange or onclick events.

When "", the software checks Globals.ControlHookupMethods. If neither supply a string, no HUCtrlFnc property is specified on client side representation of the condition object and the default hookup method is used.
See the Developer's Guide for a description of the Control Hookup Method, its parameters, and an example.
It defaults to "".

member.param: The control that will install its hookup method.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.TransferPropertiesFromControl(System.Web.UI.Control,Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseValidatorAction,System.Int32)
member.summary: TransferPropertiesFromControl allows a third party control that is connected to Validator.ControlIDToEvaluate to provide some properties to the ValidatorAction provided and its condition. This is generally used when a third party overrides a VAMTypeConverter to support its controls.

remarks.para: Some third party controls already have the same property values as the validator. So why have the user enter them twice? For example, if the control has an error message, it can copy it into ErrorMessage when ErrorMessage and ErrorMessageLookupID are both blank. For example, if this is a RangeCondition and the control has a minimum and maximum range setting, transfer those to RangeCondition.Minimum and Maximum.
See the Developer's Guide for an overview of implementing VAMTypeConverters for custom controls.

member.param: The control whose properties will be transferred to the ValidatorAction and/or Condiiton object on the validator.
The destination ValidatorAction for the properties. Its Condition property provides the Condition.
When the validator has more than one ControlIDToEvaluate, this specifies which one it is where 1 is the first, 2 is the second, etc.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.DefineJavaScript(Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMPage)
member.summary: DefineJavaScript creates whatever JavaScript that is used by this VAMTypeConverter. It should define JavaScript functions or load a file.

remarks.para: It is passed the current VAMPage class which has two methods that make registration easy:
- Call VAMPage.IsScriptBlockRegistered before registering to determine if the script was written by another instance of this class.
- If its not registered, call VAMPage.RegisterScriptBlock or VAMPage.RegisterScriptFile.

member.param: Current VAMPage object. Can get it from Globals.Page.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.Name
member.summary: The name of the data type as shown to the user in the Properties Window in the DataType property.

value.para: It is recommended to assign it a user friendly name like "integer" instead of the class name "System.Int32". However, if you do not assign it, it will get the class name from the property.

This name is used to lookup a VAMTypeConverter instance stored in the Globals.DataTypes collection (taken from the config files). The config files will identify both the VAMTypeConverter full type name and this property so it can lookup the requested type and create the correct class instance.

VAMTypeConverters have a number of properties. The user doesn't have to settle for the default values on those properties. They can define the same class under a new Name with different values for the properties. The custom.VAM.config file provides documentation to assist in redefining VAMTypeConverters with new properties.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.DataType
member.summary: The .Net Type that is the "native data type" of this VAMTypeConverter. It is used to create the that is used for the default conversion between string and native data type.

value.para: If you use a class to convert strings, you must assign this property. The TypeConverter is retrieved through TypeDescriptor.GetConverter(DataType).
The client-side does not use this as this is a .net type, not a JavaScript type.
When set, if is blank, it's set with DataType.Name.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.CSConvertFromFunction
member.summary: The name of the client-side Convert From function. It converts the string to the native data type.

value.para: Each VAMTypeConverter class must define a JavaScript function that takes a string and returns its native data type or null to indicate that conversion failed.
See the Developer's Guide for a description of this function, its parameters, and an example.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.CSConvertToFunction
member.summary: The name of the client-side Convert To function. It converts the native data type to a string.

value.para: It is only used for a DataTypeTextBox built for the data type of the VAMTypeConverter subclass. You do not need to define it when you are not creating a DataTypeTextBox around the data type.
The function is passed the native data type and returns a string.
See the Developer's Guide for a description of this function, its parameters, and an example.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.Comparer
member.summary: Class for comparing the native data types on the server side.

value.para: Server-side Condition evaluation methods often need to compare two native data types. They call BaseCondition.EvalWithOperator to compare the values. That function takes this property to assist in conversion.

If this is null, EvalWithOperator uses the interface built into many data types. If your data type does not implement IComparable, supply a class that implements the interface and assign an instance of that class here.
It defaults to null.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.CSComparerFunction
member.summary: The name of the client-side Comparer function for comparing the native data types.

value.para: Client-side Condition evaluation functions often need to compare two native data types. By default, they call "VAM_Compare" to compare the values. VAM_Compare applies the JavaScript operators against two native data types, such as value1 == value2. If your native data type cannot be compared with simple JavaScript operators, you define a replacement to VAM_Compare and assign the function name to this property.
See the Developer's Guide for a description of this function, its parameters, and an example.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.CSConvertFieldToValueFunction
member.summary: The name of the client-side Convert Field To Value function that retrieves the value from a control and returns its native value. It is designed to work with custom controls.

value.para: It is similar to the Convert From function (). However, the Convert From function only handles string to native data types. This function is used instead of the Convert From function when you have a custom control that already implements its own client-side code to return native data types. For example, that control may involve two textboxes and return JavaScript object to represent both values as the native data type.
When blank, a default function is defined, "VAM_ConvertStrFld", which calls "VAM_GetTextValue" and then converts it to a native type using the Convert From function.
See the Developer's Guide for a description of this function, its parameters, and an example.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.OneMultiplier
member.summary: When comparing two dates to determine their difference, the dates are converted into integers of milliseconds. The DifferenceCondition asks the user to enter a value for the difference. Users should be able to enter a number of days such as 1.5 for 1.5 days. The computer should convert that into milliseconds. This is a factor for converting the number the user enters.

value.para: Use 0 if the data type cannot be converted into a number. For example, strings cannot be converted and StringVAMTypeConverter sets this to 0.
Use 1 if the data type maintains the value entered by the user.
Enter another value to multiply by the Difference value to get to the value used by comparison. For example, dates use 86400000 on the client side and 24 x 60 x 60 x 10000000 on the server side.
OneMultipler is for the server side. is for the client side.
It defaults to 1.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.CSOneMultiplier
member.summary: CSOneMultipler is just like except its used on the client side.

value.para: Usually this is the same value as OneMultiplier. In the case of dates, the native Date object on the client and server side represent "ticks" differently.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VAMTypeConverter.SupportsThirdPartyControl
member.summary: SupportsThirdPartyControl indicates that the VAMTypeConverter was built for a particular control class that does not implement the .

value.para: When true, the method is available for use by the ControlConnection class to see if a particular control is supported by this VAMTypeConverter. Basically, VAMTypeConverter can extend the list of valid controls when this is true.
When true, you must override and .
See the Developer's Guide for an overview of implementing VAMTypeConverters for custom controls.
It defaults to false.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.DateVAMTypeConverter
member.summary: DateVAMTypeConverter provides the comparision and conversions for Dates.

remarks.para: The DataType is . However, it does not use the for conversion. Instead it overrides and to convert strings using the culture settings in VAMPage.CultureInfo.

It supports dates according to the CultureInfo.DateTimeFormatInfo.ShortDatePattern. It is limited to digits in Month, Day and Year parts. (In other words, it does not support 'dd/MMM/yyy' where the abbreviated month is used. For that, you can use Peter's Date Package which provides an alternative Date-based VAMTypeConverter.)
It also supports yyyy-MM-dd format automatically because Microsoft's validators do.

member.summary: Adds the following properties to the client-side condition object: Pattern, DateSep, CentBrk.

remarks.para: The following properties are added to the client-side representation of the condition object:

item.description: The order of the short date pattern with this format: M|D|Y. The M, D, and Y characters are ordered based on VAMPage.CultureInfo.DateTimeFormatInfo.ShortDatePattern. The pipe is always between each of these.
The Date Separator from VAMPage.CultureInfo.DateTimeFormatInfo.DateSeparator.
For two digit years, the century break. Must be 0-99. Gets the value from GregorianCalendar.TwoDigitYearMax which gets its value from the Regional Settings control panel.

remarks.para: The following properties are added to the client-side representation of the DataTypeTextBoxValidatorAction object:

item.description: Formats of the string. Should be a short date format with M, MM, D, DD, YY, YYYY as tokens that substitute for values. All letters are uppercase. M and D - no lead zero. YY - 2 digit year.

member.summary: While can request the use of that symbol in reformatting, the CultureInfo.NumberFormat.CurrencyGroupSeparator and CultureInfo.NumberFormat.NumberGroupSeparator may be "", which subclasses should detect and turn off the feature.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CurrencyVAMTypeConverter
member.summary: CurrencyVAMTypeConverter provides the conversions between strings containing currency values and their native data type, System.Double.

remarks.para: The currency string may have culture specific currency symbols, thousands separators, decimal points, and negative notations.

There are two forms of currency: with and without currency symbol. The
property determines which to use.
The DataType is Double. However, it does not use the for conversion. Instead it overrides and to convert strings using the culture settings in VAMPage.CultureInfo.NumberFormat.

Conversion from string to double uses Double.Parse with the NumberStyles = Currency when UseCurrencySymbol is true and not provided when false. On the client side, it emulates the Double.Parse function with the "VAM_CurrFmt" Convert From Function.
The format can be:
Rules for converting from a string to a double:

item.description: When '(' appears, so must ')'
Groupseparators are allowed in any position including a series: 1,,,000 is OK. 1,2,3,0.00 is OK'
Groupseparators cannot appear after the decimal separator
Number of digits for decimal part is not limited in Double.Parse. Here UseDecimalDigits determines if that rule works.
Only one currency symbol is allowed. For example, $1.00$ is illegal
Currency symbol can be anywhere except within the digits. $(1.00) ($1.00) (1.00$) (1.00)$
Trim lead and trailing spaces
Cannot have spaces between +|-|( and first digit unless separated by currency symbol "$ 1.00" is OK "- 1.00" is not.
No more than one decimal separator allowed

member.summary: Converts from the string to a double.

remarks.para: It does not use the . Instead it uses Double.Parse with the VAMPage.CultureInfo.NumberFormat. If UseCurrencySymbol is true, it sets the Double.Parse method to use NumberStyles.Currency as a parameter. This ensures using the currency properties of NumberFormat.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.MetaControls.Attributes.RadioButtonListMetaControlAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to declare the need for a preference or setting to be displayed as a RadioButtonList
member.remarks:
This attribute can be applied to either a portlet or an application.
It will be used by the framework to automatically generate the appropriate preferences or settings overlay that allows the user to enter the data for that preference or setting using the control specified.
This information can then be retrieved by using the various preference and settings domain objects in the framework. They can also be accessed by using the Preferences or Settings property of the PortletBase and PortalApplicationBase classes.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SPanel
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the Panel control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.SHyperLink
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the HyperLink control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseSpecialCondition
member.summary: BaseSpecialCondition is a base class for any condition that doesn't evaluate user assigned data within form input fields.

remarks.para: It has the following features:

item.description: It is based on so the user can select a control to evaluate.
It allows the selection of any control on the page through the class.
It hides these properties from the Property Editor: Trim, NotCondition (subclasses may add them back if needed).
It sets EvaluateOnClickOrChange to false avoiding hooking up the onchange/onclick events.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.VisibleCondition
member.summary: VisibleCondition is a specialized condition that determines if the ControlToEvaluate is visible or not.

remarks.para: For example, a Validator's property may use the VisibleCondition to prevent a validator from validating a control that is invisible.
Set the property to the control and Visibility state with the property.
See the User's Guide for an overview of using this condition.

Visibility is determined by the style.visibility and style.display attributes. An object is invisible if style.visibility = 'hidden' OR style.display = 'none'. Note that the ControlToEvaluate.Visible property is not involved. After all, when its false, no control is generated into the client-side page.

Note:Visibility is not determined by the WebControl.Visible property because that is really an on-off switch. When set to false, the entire webcontrol is not written to the page. The client-side has nothing available to detect the state of the control since it is not on the page.

member.summary: Evaluates as "success" when the visibility of the control matches the property. Evaluates as "failed" otherwise. There is no "cannot evaluate" state.

remarks.para: Looks at the Styles[] collection for "Visibility" and "Display" attributes. Ignores the Visible property as that entirely removes the object from the client-side.

member.returns: 1 for "success"; 0 for "failed".

member.summary: IsVisible is the visibility state of the control that we are evaluating.

value.para: When IsVisible is true, we expect the control to be visible on the page.
When false, we expect the control to be invisible on the page by checking the style 'visibility' for a value of 'hidden' or the style 'display' for a value of 'none'.
It defaults to true.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.EnabledCondition
member.summary: EnabledCondition is a specialized condition that determines if the ControlToEvaluate is enabled or disabled.

remarks.para: For example, a Validator's property may use the EnabledCondition to prevent a validator from validating a control that is disabled.
Set the property to the control and Enabled state with the property.
See the User's Guide for an overview of using this condition.

On the client side, enabled is determined by the HTML disabled attribute. Note that many HTML elements may not support the disabled property on the client side. Only Internet Explorer 5+ provides support for it on most data entry fields.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseAttributeCondition
member.summary: BaseAttributeCondition is a base class that allows the user to define the name and value of any attribute or style on the ControlToEvaluate within DOM/DHTML.

remarks.para: The user must know the DOM/DHTML attribute or style name and compatible values. The client-side will set and get them with the JavaScript "eval()" function.

The user must select an AttributeType -- Attribute or Style -- that determines if the field attributes or field style sheet attributes are modified. The server side will look at the Attributes or Styles collections on the control. The client side will look at:
eval(field.attrname) or eval(field.style.attrname)

The user must determine the datatype of the attribute: string, integer, or boolean. This is used in making the comparison and formatting the value as its passed to the client side. (For example, it always puts quotes around strings. If you have boolean value, putting quotes around 'true' or 'false' make those into strings, not boolean values.)
Subclasses define the actual comparision rules and properties.

member.summary: AttributeName is the name of the attribute or style, specific to the browser (DHTML or DOM) found on the control to evaluate.

value.para: On the server side, it is used in the Control.Attributes[Name] or Control.Style[Name] properties. On the client side, it is used in eval(control.Name) or eval(control.style.Name).
Browsers are case sensitive to attribute and style names.
It is required. When "", the condition cannot be evaluated.
It defaults to "".

It defaults to AttributeDataType.String.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Secured.STextBox
member.summary: A secured, operation aware version of the TextBox control
member.remarks:
Secured controls can be used to make interface elements aware of whether or not a user has access to a particular operation assigned to the control
If the user does not have access to the operation(s) assigned to the control, the control can be set to render differently (or not at all) to prevent the user from using the control to perform the secured operation
In addition, events normally raised by the control will not be raised if the control detects that the access check has failed. This prevents users from "spoofing" access by simulating a postback.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction
member.summary: The and controls both use this for their subclass.

remarks.para: This Action is assigned a condition from the user's selection, either through the constructor, Condition parameter, or by the FieldStateController object.

It uses two properties to represent the values used when the condition succeeds and fails: and . Most of these values are only set on the client side. Only when a setting differs between ConditionTrue and ConditionFalse will the attribute be changed.
This class is designed to be subclassed so you can introduce a subclass of StateSettings. Override the method.
