member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.DoActionBody(System.Boolean)
member.summary: DoActionBody handles the initial settings of the ControlToChange as the page is rendered.

remarks.para: It gets called automatically within VAMPage.PagePreRender.
It only applies the Visible, Enabled, ReadOnly, and CssClass properties when ConditionTrue and ConditionFalse differ on the same properties. The rest are handled on the client-side code exclusively.
Uses to do the work.

member.param: When true, the condition was successful; when false, it failed.

member.name: M:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.OnStateChange(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Changes the attributes and properties on the server side prior to sending the page out.

remarks.para: Both the client and server side have some code to initialize the ControlToChange based on and . This is the server side part. It initializes visibility, enabled, readonly, style sheet class, and runs the event.
The client-side function, "VAM_InitFieldState", handles all the rest. Any property that needs to preserve the initial setting is handled on the client-side so it can capture the initial setting.

member.param: When true, the condition was successful; when false, it failed.

member.summary: ControlIDToChange is the ID to the control whose state will be changed.

value.para: This is ID property, not the ClientID or UniqueID. It will be translated into the ClientID at runtime.
If this ID is unassigned, this Action is not used.
If the control cannot be found in the current or any parent NamingContainer, an exception is thrown at runtime.
Internally, the ID is stored in

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.ControlToChange
member.summary: Gets and sets a reference to the control whose state will be changed.

value.para: As a reference to the control, it can refer to any control on the page, whereas the property must refer to a control within the same or parent Naming Container as this FieldStateController.
When ControlIDToChange is assigned, getting a value here will attempt to find the control on the page and return its instance.
Assignment must be done programmatically.
Internally, the reference is stored in

member.summary:
ControlToChangeConnection is used by and
for data storage and validation of the control class.

value.para: When first used, it creates a object for the storage.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.InvisiblePreservesSpace
member.summary: InvisiblePreservesSpace determines if a control takes up space on the page when its state is changed to invisible.

value.para: When the ConditionTrue.Visible or ConditionFalse.Visible property causes the field to be hidden, there are two ways the field can be hidden: Preserve the space of the element or remove the element entirely.

This depends on the client-side style attributes 'display' and 'visibility'. When true, the style is set to visibility:hidden with no change to the display style. When false, the style is visibility:hidden;display:none.

The client-side code preserves the original value of the 'display' attribute before changing it so that when the element becomes visible once again, the display style is restored to its original value.
It defaults to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.RunFunctionName
member.summary: RunFunctionName defines the name of an optional client-side function to call to handle the state change. It allows you to customize the state change.

value.para: A good usage is when the element on the page is already managed by client-side functions and supplies a function for you to call to change its state.
If you want to run a function, create it in JavaScript on the page.
It takes these parameters:

item.description: Client-side representation of the field state object. It allows you to get properties like CssClass, Enabled and Visible for use in your function.
The element that is being operated upon. It is an object for the element. If you need the objects ID, this object has a property called id.
When true, the condition indicates success; false indicates the condition failed.

value.para: It does not return a result.
See the User's Guide for more details and an example.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.ConditionTrue
member.summary:
ConditionTrue contains the state settings to apply to the
when the Condition evaluates as 'success'.

value.para:
Settings are only applied at runtime when both this and
differ on a property-by-property basis.
To provide additional properties, subclass to add the properties and override to return to the class.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.ConditionFalse
member.summary:
ConditionFalse contains the state settings to apply to the
when the Condition evaluates as 'failed'.

value.para:
Settings are only applied at runtime when both this and
differ on a property-by-property basis.
To provide additional properties, subclass to add the properties and override to return to the class.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.UseValidationGroup
member.summary: UseValidationGroup enables running all validators matching upon completion of the FieldState change.

value.para: Use this when you have a validator that is associated with a field whose state is changed with this FieldStateController and should either be shown or hidden. The validator should have its BaseAnyValidator.Enabler property set to detect the state of the field changed, usually using or . So when the validators are rerun on the page, your validator will disabled or enable itself.
It only affects the client-side changes.
It runs just like a Submit action does, including an update of ValidationSummary.
It defaults to false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.ValidationGroup
member.summary:
ValidationGroup defines a group name used by validators. When
is true, all validators matching this group name are run after the field state has changed. This allows validators to remove themselves when the state no longer supports them.

value.para: Use "*" to run through all groups.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.ControlIDToRunThisAction
member.summary: ControlIDToRunThisAction is the ID to the control that runs this action when the user clicks on it. It is only used in special situations because the Condition property usually provides a control that will run this FieldStateController.

value.para: When the FieldStateController should run based on a data-oriented element like textbox, list, or checkbox, the Condition property will specify that control. When the FieldStateController should be run by clicking on a non-data-oriented element like label, button, or image, use this property to specify that control.

This is ID property, not the ClientID or UniqueID. It will be translated into the ClientID at runtime. If the ID is assigned but the control cannot be found in the current or any parent NamingContainer, an exception is thrown at runtime.
This sets the ControlID property of .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateAction.ControlToRunThisAction
member.summary:
ControlToRunThisAction is an alternative to
that maintains a reference to the control.

value.para: As a reference to the control, it can refer to any control on the page, whereas the property must refer to a control within the same or parent Naming Container as this FieldStateController.
When ControlIDToRunThisAction is assigned, getting a value here will attempt to find the control on the page and return its instance.
Assignment must be done programmatically.
Internally, the reference is stored in .

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.FieldStateAction

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings
member.summary: StateSettings contains the state settings used by the and properties on the and controls.

remarks.para: Its properties provide an extensive list of attributes that can be changed on a control. It even provides the where you can enter the name of a DOM/DHTML property and the value you want to set.

It is designed to allow expansion through subclassing when the user identifies a new state to manage. When subclassed, also subclass to override BaseFieldStateAction.CreateStateSettings with the new class and BaseFieldStateAction.DefineProperties with the new properties.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.Visible
member.summary: Visible determines whether the control is visible or not.

value.para: Visibility changes the style attribute 'visibility', not the WebControl property 'Visible'. When the WebControl.Visible property is false, ASP.NET never generates any HTML representing the control to the client side. So you cannot later show the control on the client side. The style 'visibility' does not interfere with generating HTML for the control.
When true, it is visible.
When false, it is hidden. BaseFieldStateAction.InvisiblePreservesSpace determines if it also retains or loses the space it occupies.
It defaults to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.Enabled
member.summary: Enabled is used on controls that support the HTML property Disabled.

value.para: When true, the control is enabled (Disabled=false)
When false, the control is disabled.
It defaults to true.
Note: Most browsers support enabled on a TextBox (<input type='text'/>). Consult the browsers documentation for support of other form entry fields.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.ReadOnly
member.summary: ReadOnly is used on controls that support the HTML property ReadOnly.

value.para: When true, the control is readonly.
When false, the control is editable.
It defaults to false.
Note: Most browsers support readonly on a TextBox (<input type='text'/>). Consult the browsers documentation for support of other form entry fields.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.CssClass
member.summary: CssClass is the Class name for a style sheet that is used by the control.

value.para: It can be "", to represent the default style.
Since the style includes so many visual attributes, a style sheet is used instead of separate properties defined with the or CssStyleCollection classes.
You can use the property if you want to set an individual style.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.FieldValue
member.summary: FieldValue is the textual value of form element: input, button or textarea.

value.para: If the ControlToChange has a client-side 'value' attribute (input, button and textarea), it changes that attribute. Otherwise it does nothing.
When "", it automatically uses the initial value found on the page. This means that you only have to set this property to change the initial value.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.InnerHTML
member.summary: InnerHTML changes the innerHTML of the ControlToChange. The user can supply HTML or straight text.

value.para: When "", it automatically uses the initial value found on the page. This means that you only have to set this property to change the initial value.
It defaults to "".
Note: Not all HTML elements support innerHTML. Consult a DOM/DHTML manual to determine if this property is supported.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.URL
member.summary: URL changes the href or src attributes of the ControlToChange. These elements include , , ,

value.para: Provide whatever text is compatible with these properties including URL and scripts, with the JavaScript: leader.
When "", it automatically uses the initial value found on the page. This means that you only have to set this property to change the initial value.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.StateSettings.Other
member.summary: Other allows you to define an attribute that isn't defined in the other settings.

value.para: You must supply a valid name in the AttributeName property and associate it with the datatype, attribute style and value all compatible with the attribute or style that you are referencing.

The attribute name you supply here does not have to appear on both ConditionTrue and ConditionFalse. If they don't share the same AttributeName, when the client-side initializes, it will use the current value. This way, you can actually have two attribute names.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.ChangeStateEventHandler
member.summary: ChangeStateEventHandler is a server side event handler that allows the ControlIDToChange to be setup in a custom way. It is used in BaseFieldStateAction.StateChange.

remarks.para: It is the server side equivalent of BaseFieldStateAction.RunFunctionName.
Use it to handle more complex controls or state settings not handled by StateSettings class.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController
member.summary: Base class to the and controls.

remarks.para: BaseFieldStateController is a control that supports the classes. As a control, it appears on the ASP.NET page. However, it does not generate any HTML of its own. Instead, it sets up FieldStateAction instances for one or more controls on the page and the FieldStateActions do all the work. (On server side, their method runs during VAMPage.PagePreRegister. On the client side, they have extensive javascript to handle actions.)

This base class provides properties needed by the FieldStateAction objects including the ConditionTrue, ConditionFalse, InvisiblePreservesSpace, and RunFunctionName. However, it doesn't provide the ControlToChange. Two subclasses determine the ControlToChange:
FieldStateController - set up one ControlToChange. Creates one FieldStateAction.
MultiFieldStateController - set up a collection of ControlToChange in . Creates a of FieldStateActions.
OnPreRender creates the FieldStateAction instances and transfers the properties to them.
The user must select a Condition on the property. There is a UITypeEditor to let the user choose one. If there is no Condition, an exception is thrown.

Validation needs to run these actions as they change the UI and affect SpecialConditions (visibility, enabled, etc) After this is called, any changes to this object are ignored.

member.summary: TransferProperties copies all properties from this class to the FieldStateAction.

remarks.para: A design philosophy of this class is to expose properties of the FieldStateAction by keeping local values of the properties and to transfer those values to the actual FieldStateAction during this method.
The caller already handled setting the Owner, Condition, and ControlToChange. Override this to handle other properties on this control that must be transferred.

member.param: Transfer properties to this object.

member.summary: Returns the name of this control + "." for use in error messages.
member.remarks: The name is either the ID or the class type. It uses Globals.GetControlName to do the work.
member.returns: This control's ID or its class type.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.Condition
member.summary: The Condition class selected by the user to determine whether to use the or properties.

value.para: It provides the UITypeEditor to select the condition in the Properties Editor.

The Properties Editor and ASP.NET Attributes do not support a way to write out a polymorphic property. So this property is not written into the ASP.NET text. Instead, the object is kept in the collection and limits that collection to one item. ASP.NET attributes can write out a collection and provides with a workaround to the polymorphism problem.
Transferred to BaseFieldStateAction.Condition in OnPreRender.
It uses this ASP.NET format:

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ConditionContainer
member.summary: ConditionContainer is a hack to allow the property to stream between ASP.NET and an object.

value.para: The Condition property itself doesn't stream but modifies this list as a hack to work around a limitation in the ASP.NET attributes that don't know how to handle a polymorphic property.
This class streams to the ASP.NET text but does not appear in the Properties Editor.
You shouldn't attempt to add more than one condition as only the first will be applied to Condition.
It uses this ASP.NET format:

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.Enabled
member.summary: Enabled determines if the object is used or not.

value.para: When true, it is available for use. When false, it does nothing.

You must set this to false when another control whose Visible property is false is referenced by this control. For example, Condition.ControlIDToEvaluate, ControlIDToChange, and ControlIDToRunThisAction. Otherwise a runtime exception will occur.
It defaults to true.
Transferred to BaseFieldStateAction.Enabled in OnPreRender.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.Enabler
member.summary: Enabler is a condition which runs prior to the rest of the conditions. Use it to turn on and off the FieldStateController based on conditions on the page. For example, this FieldStateController should not run unless a certain checkbox is checked.

value.para: When no enabler is needed, it is null.
It provides the UITypeEditor to select the condition in the Properties Editor.

The Properties Editor and ASP.NET Attributes do not support a way to write out a polymorphic property. So this property is not written into the ASP.NET text. Instead, the object is kept in the collection and limits that collection to one item. ASP.NET attributes can write out a collection and provides with a workaround to the polymorphism problem.
Transferred to BaseFieldStateAction.Enabler in OnPreRender.
It uses this ASP.NET format:

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.EnablerContainer
member.summary: EnablerContainer is a hack to allow the property to stream between ASP.NET and an object.

value.para: The Enabler property itself doesn't stream but modifies this list as a hack to work around a limitation in the ASP.NET attributes that don't know how to handle a polymorphic property.
This class streams to the ASP.NET text but does not appear in the Properties Editor.
You shouldn't attempt to add more than one condition as only the first will be applied to Enabler.
It uses this ASP.NET format:

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.InvisiblePreservesSpace
member.summary: InvisiblePreservesSpace determines if a control takes up space on the page when its state is changed to invisible.

value.para: When the ConditionTrue.Visible or ConditionFalse.Visible property causes the field to be hidden, there are two ways the field can be hidden: Preserve the space of the element or remove the element entirely.

This depends on the client-side style attributes 'display' and 'visibility'. When true, the style is set to visibility:hidden with no change to the display style. When false, the style is visibility:hidden;display:none.

The client-side code preserves the original value of the 'display' attribute before changing it so that when the element becomes visible once again, the display style is restored to its original value.
It defaults to true.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.RunFunctionName
member.summary: RunFunctionName defines the name of an optional client-side function to call to handle the state change. It allows you to customize the state change.

value.para: A good usage is when the element on the page is already managed by client-side functions and supplies a function for you to call to change its state.
If you want to run a function, create it in JavaScript on the page.
It takes these parameters:

item.description: Client-side representation of the field state object. It allows you to get properties like CssClass, Enabled and Visible for use in your function.
The element that is being operated upon. It is an object for the element. If you need the objects ID, this object has a property called id.
When true, the condition indicates success; false indicates the condition failed.

value.para: It does not return a result.
See the User's Guide for more details and an example.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ConditionTrue
member.summary: ConditionTrue contains the state settings to apply to the FieldStateController.ControlIDToChange or MultiFieldStateController.ControlConnections when the Condition evaluates as 'success'.

value.para:
Settings are only applied at runtime when both this and
differ on a property-by-property basis.
To provide additional properties, subclass to add the properties and override to return to the class.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ConditionFalse
member.summary: ConditionFalse contains the state settings to apply to the FieldStateController.ControlIDToChange or MultiFieldStateController.ControlConnections when the Condition evaluates as 'failed'.

value.para:
Settings are only applied at runtime when both this and
differ on a property-by-property basis.
To provide additional properties, subclass to add the properties and override to return to the class.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.UseValidationGroup
member.summary: UseValidationGroup enables running all validators matching upon completion of the FieldState change.

value.para: Use this when you have a validator that is associated with a field whose state is changed with this FieldStateController and should either be shown or hidden. The validator should have its BaseAnyValidator.Enabler property set to detect the state of the field changed, usually using or . So when the validators are rerun on the page, your validator will disabled or enable itself.
It only affects the client-side changes.
It runs just like a Submit action does, including an update of ValidationSummary.
It defaults to false.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ValidationGroup
member.summary:
ValidationGroup defines a group name used by validators. When
is true, all validators matching this group name are run after the field state has changed. This allows validators to remove themselves when the state no longer supports them.

value.para: Use "*" to run through all groups.
It defaults to "".

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ControlIDToRunThisAction
member.summary: ControlIDToRunThisAction is the ID to the control that runs this action when the user clicks on it. It is only used in special situations because the Condition property usually provides a control that will run this FieldStateController.

value.para: When the FieldStateController should run based on a data-oriented element like textbox, list, or checkbox, the Condition property will specify that control. When the FieldStateController should be run by clicking on a non-data-oriented element like label, button, or image, use this property to specify that control.

This is ID property, not the ClientID or UniqueID. It will be translated into the ClientID at runtime. If the ID is assigned but the control cannot be found in the current or any parent NamingContainer, an exception is thrown at runtime.
This sets the ControlID property of .

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ControlToRunThisAction
member.summary:
ControlToRunThisAction is an alternative to
that maintains a reference to the control.

value.para: As a reference to the control, it can refer to any control on the page, whereas the property must refer to a control within the same or parent Naming Container as this FieldStateController.
When ControlIDToRunThisAction is assigned, getting a value here will attempt to find the control on the page and return its instance.
Assignment must be done programmatically.
Internally, the reference is stored in

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.BaseFieldStateController.ControlToRunThisActionConnection
member.summary:
ControlToRunThisActionConnection is used by and
for data storage and validation of the control class.

value.para: When first used, it creates a object for the storage.

member.summary: The Visible property is not used because it has mixed meanings. It is an on/off switch for a control. So is Enabled. Enabled is used as the on/off switch for this control.
member.value: Overridden to hide this property from the Properties Editor and prevent streaming.

member.name: T:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CSAttributeDesc
member.summary: CSAttributeDesc describes an Attribute or Style on a client-side field. It defines a value for that style. It is an element of the class which is used on FieldStateController controls.

remarks.para: Together the attribute and value are used in BaseFieldStateAction.ConditionTrue and BaseFieldStateAction.ConditionFalse to change the attribute based on the condition. Its goal is to allow the user to extend the list of attributes available within StateSettings. StateSettings defines the property to hold this.
The user must supply a valid DHTML/DOM attribute name. An invalid name will cause a JavaScript error at runtime.
Attributes must have a DataType declared so the value can be formatted correctly.
The value may be "" if the DataType is a string. Otherwise, it must be a valid representation for the value on the client side.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CSAttributeDesc.AttributeName
member.summary: AttributeName is the name of the client side attribute or style. It is required and must be a valid DOM/DHTML name.

value.para: Attributes and styles are properties on a client-side object. They are defined by the browser product, usually following some or all of the DHTML or DOM standards. You must research the browsers that you want to support and their use of the DHTML or DOM standards to determine the name of the attribute, and its possible values. You may find that some browser do not support the attribute.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CSAttributeDesc.Value
member.summary: Value is a string representation of the value to be assigned to the attribute.
member.value: It's textual format must be compatible with the datatype of the Attribute in a JavaScript assignment statement. For example, only strings support "". Boolean must be "false" and "true". Integer must be entirely digits.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CSAttributeDesc.DataType
member.summary: DataType determines the data type of the Attribute or style. It must match the defined datatype or you may get JavaScript errors.

value.para: It defaults to AttributeDataType.String.

member.name: P:Jenzabar.Portal.Framework.Web.UI.Controls.Validation.CSAttributeDesc.AttributeType
member.summary: AttributeType determines if the AttributeName is an Attribute or Style of the field.

value.para: It defaults to AttributeType.Attribute.
